  • 3.3.4 Reset Existing Delta Sync Configuration
  • 3.4 End-to-End Monitoring of Employee Master Data Replication
  • 3.4.1 Monitoring Across Systems
  • 3.4.2 Monitoring in SAP Integration Suite
  • 4. Lessons Learned
  • 5. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series – each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side – Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Why is this Integration required?

Integrating employee data from SAP SuccessFactors into SAP EHS Public Cloud is a foundational step for enabling core EHS processes such as Incident Management, Risk Management, and Emissions Management. Instead of maintaining employee data locally within SAP EHS Public Cloud, the system relies on Workforce Person master data replicated from the corporate HR system. This ensures that roles, organizational assignments, and reporting lines remain consistent across the enterprise.

Accurate and up-to-date employee data is essential in Environment, Health & Safety (EHS), as many process steps are people-driven – including incident reporting, assigning investigation responsibilities, approvals, and regulatory documentation. Moreover, EHS integrated workflow functionalities are heavily based on a role and responsibility concept, which depends on the correct assignment of persons within the organization.

In other words: Without employee integration, SAP EHS Public Cloud cannot correctly identify, assign, or document the people involved in an incident or are responsible for EHS tasks.

Architectural Approach - Scope

The highlighted section of the architectural diagram illustrates the scope relevant to this blog post - focusing on the integration of employees from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Note: While this post focuses on the standard integration scenario using SAP SuccessFactors EC as the source, employee master data can also be replicated from other connected HR systems or SAP S/4HANA On-Premise / Private Cloud environments. In such cases, a customized integration flow can be implemented in SAP Integration Suite to transfer the workforce data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. If the integration to the relevant HR system already exists, this step can be skipped.

Reference to User Scenario (A) – Incident Management

In part 1 "Introduction & Overview”, the User Scenario (A) Incident Management at Mike Machineries (chapter 2.1.1) clearly demonstrated why this integration is required:

Scenario Step

Why Employee Integration Matters

An internal maintenance technician is injured

The injured person must be identified as an employee, with job role, organizational unit, and location stored to support injury documentation, reporting and regulatory requirements.

A colleague nearby reports the incident in the system

The system must recognize the reporter as an employee with the correct role and permission to create an incident entry.

A First Aider records medical details in the Injury/Illness Log Entry

EHS needs accurate employee data to identify the certified First Aider and capture their involvement for documentation and accountability.

The Incident Manager is automatically notified and assigned

The Incident Manager must be derived from organizational structures, supervisory relationships, or assigned safety roles maintained in HR.

Corrective and preventive actions are assigned to employees

Task ownership, due dates, approvals, and completion tracking require valid employee master data to ensure accountability and reporting across the organization.

Learnings are shared across sites with operations and safety teams

Up-to-date organizational structures ensure that communication reaches the right target audience for safety awareness and training measures.

Without integrated employee data, the system would not be able to:

  • Identify the injured person, reporter or First Aider,
  • Determine the responsible Incident Manager, or
  • Track assigned corrective actions across organizational units.

This makes the integration of employees from SAP SuccessFactors EC into SAP EHS Public Cloud a mandatory first step before configuring Incident Management.

Note: When implementing Incident Management as shown here in the user scenario, please ensure that scope item 3FP – Incident Management is activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Central Business Configuration (CBC) beforehand. This activation is required to enable the Incident Management processes and related configuration in SAP EHS Public Cloud.

While this integration is a prerequisite for Incident Management, it is equally relevant across other EHS use cases such as Risk Management or Emissions Management. In these scenarios, consistent employee master data provides the foundation for assigning roles and responsibilities, managing organizational structures, and ensuring accurate process execution and compliance. Therefore, in the following section, we will take a closer look at the general setup of the employee data integration between SAP SuccessFactors and SAP EHS Public Cloud.

 

2. Prerequisites

To successfully set up the integration scenario for SAP EHS Public Cloud, several prerequisites must be met. These prerequisites ensure that employee master data can be replicated from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud using the predefined integration scenario delivered with scope item JB1 – Maintain Employee Master Data.

Important: Activating scope item JB1 enables the required communication scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, allowing the predefined integration flows in SAP Integration Suite to securely exchange and replicate employee data between the two systems.

To successfully set up this integration scenario, the following prerequisites must be in place:

Tenant Provisioning:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC tenant
  • SAP Cloud Integration tenant (SAP Integration Suite)

Certificate Setup:

  • Certificates are required only if certificate-based authentication is used for the connection (recommended for productive environments)
  • In our case, Basic Authentication was used for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, and OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion for SAP SuccessFactors, which requires a Key Pair in the SAP Integration Suite instead of an X.509 certificate exchange.

Administrator Access: Admin users must be available across all three systems:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - The administrator should have the template role of SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR to allow creation of communication users, systems, and arrangements.
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC
  • SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) / SAP Integration Suite

Scope Item Activation:

  • Scope item "Core HR with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (JB1)" must be activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

Data Requirements:

  • Legal entities in SAP SuccessFactors must match the Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Mismatches will lead to replication failures).

Employee Import Restriction:

  • Once employees have been replicated from SAP SuccessFactors EC to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, do not manually create or upload the same employee (e.g., via Manage Workforce app). Mixing manually created records with replicated records can lead to data inconsistencies and replication conflicts.

 

3. Technical Integration

This section describes the practical implementation of the employee data integration based on the predefined JB1 – Core HR with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central scope item. It outlines how workforce data is replicated from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and highlights the key configuration areas involved in the process.

The JB1 scope item provides the standard integration scenario for workforce data replication and supports related HR data flows relevant for Incident, Risk, and Emissions Management. Accurate and consistent employee master data is crucial for these EHS use cases, as incidents, responsibilities, and corrective actions depend on properly linked workforce information.

Therefore, this section focuses on the JB1 – Maintain Employee Master Data process, which serves as the foundation for all subsequent EHS configurations.

Key JB1 Configuration Areas:

  • SAP SuccessFactors EC Configuration
  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • Integration Package Setup in SAP Cloud Integration
  • Monitoring and Operations

For a detailed documentation, please refer to the official JB1 content in the SAP Process Navigator - SAP for Me.

How to find JB1 setup instructions as a PDF

To view the process visualization, open JB1 – 02 Maintain Employee Master Data in the SAP Process Navigator.

Select "Maintain Employee Master Data" process flow

 

"Maintain Employee Master Data" process flow

 3.1 SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) Configuration

To prepare SAP SuccessFactors EC for the employee master data replication to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, several configuration steps must be completed upfront. In our setup, SAP SuccessFactors was already fully implemented and configured, and our focus was primarily on enabling the integration with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Nevertheless, we have summarized the key configuration steps below to outline the main areas that typically need to be in place to support the JB1 replication scenario. For a detailed, step-by-step configuration, the official SAP Best Practice documentation can be referenced (JB1 setup instructions – chapter 3).

Provisioning Settings in EC

The configuration begins in SuccessFactors Provisioning, where core system settings must be enabled to support employee data replication. This includes activating EC core features, ensuring required language packs are available, and enabling the necessary integration add-ons and OData APIs. These provisioning settings form the technical foundation that allows EC to supply employee data to external systems, including SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Push Replication Setup (Optional but Recommended)

Employee data can be transferred to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud either through scheduled replication jobs or by using push replication. Push replication enables near-real-time updates and is recommended for scenarios where timely employee data is needed, such as EHS processes. If enables, additional configuration is required to specify which employee changes trigger replication and to define the conditions under which data is pushed to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Data Model Configuration (HRIS & MDF)

To ensure compatibility with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, key elements of the EC data model should be validated and adjusted if necessary. This includes checking HRIS elements for correctness, making sure mandatory fields are maintained, and aligning field properties such as formatting, field length, and data type. MDF objects must also be reviewed for employee-related data elements so that required data can be successfully replicated. Aligning the data model upfront minimizes replication error and ensures that all data transferred to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud meets the expected structure.

Company Structure and Cost Assignment Alignments

Employee data must be linked to the correct organizational units to enable downstream processes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, including EHS. It is important to ensure that Legal Entities, Business Units, Departments, and Cost Centers are correctly structured and assigned. In some cases, custom fields may be required to support additional mapping between EC and S/4HANA, depending on the company’s organizational structure. A clear alignment of this data ensures that employees appear in the correct organizational context after replication.

Integration User and Authentication Setup

An integration user with appropriate permissions must be created to allow SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to retrieve employee data through EC APIs. This includes assigning the required OData API permissions and confirming that the chosen authentication method – basic authentication or certificate-based authentication – is correctly configured. Basic authentication is typically sufficient for testing or demonstration purposes, while certificate-based authentication is recommended for productive environments.

Optional EC Application Settings

In addition to the core configuration steps, EC provides optional settings that can enhance the quality of employee data replicated to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. These include settings such as employee information, and contingent worker data. While not mandatory for the integration, these options can enrich the employee profile in the target system.

3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration

In addition to setting up SAP SuccessFactors EC, the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must also be configured to receive employee master data via the SAP Integration Suite. For this purpose, a Communication Arrangement is required to enable secure data exchange between the systems. In this scenario, the predefined Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001 – Employee Integration is used. Activating and configuring this Communication Arrangement enables the necessary inbound API services, allowing the SAP Integration Suite to push employee data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Setup illustration of Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001

As shown in the illustration above, the Communication Arrangement consists of two key components: an Inbound Communication User and a Communication System.

3.2.1 Communication User

In this integration scenario, an Inbound Communication User was created in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (e.g. user SF_S4HC). This user was used for Basic Authentication in the Communication Arrangement, and its credentials were securely stored later in the Security Material of SAP Integration Suite to enable a safe connection between the systems.

To create the Inbound Communication User in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, log in to the Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the app “Maintain Communication Users”.

Select "Maintain Communication User"

 If no suitable user exists, simply select “New” to create one.

Select New Communication User

Username and password can be freely defined but must be entered later in the Security Material section of the SAP Integration Suite for authentication.

Illustration of our Communication User

These steps align with chapter 5.2 “Integration Credentials Configuration” in the JB1 setup instructions (pages 29–30). For more details on using Certificate-based Authentication instead of Basic Authentication, please refer to the corresponding JB1 guide section.

3.2.2 Communication System

The Communication System defines the technical connection between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the external system, in this case SAP Integration Suite. It contains system details such as URLs, authentication methods, and technical identifiers, forming the foundation for all Communication Arrangements that enable secure data exchange. Without a properly configured Communication System, no reliable integration between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and SAP Integration Suite can take place.

In our setup, the SAP Integration Suite tenant served as the Communication System. If no system exists yet, a new one needs to be created in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. For basic incident management scenarios, this single system is sufficient. However, for additional integrations – such as cost center replication or payroll posting etc. – further configuration might be required (For reference, see chapter 4.1.2 “Create Communication Systems” in the  JB1 setup instructions, pages 30-31).

To create the Communication System, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the “Communication Systems” app.

Select "Communication Systems"

 If no suitable entry is available, create a new system by selecting “New”.

Select New Communication System

 Enter a System ID and System Name referring to the Integration Suite tenant and proceed with the set up.

System Setup

After creating the new Communication System entry, additional configuration details must be maintained – including General Data, Technical Data, Log System ID, Business System ID, and the User for Inbound Communication. These parameters define how SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud connects with the external SAP Integration Suite tenant.

For comprehensive configuration guidance, refer to the JB1 setup instructions. In our setup, the Communication System was created with the settings illustrated below.

Illustration of our Communication System (1)Illustration of our Communication System (2)

 3.2.3 Communication Arrangement

The final step in the S/4HANA Public Cloud configuration is to bind the previously created components – the Communication User and the Communication System – within the Communication Arrangement (SAP_COM_0001 – Employee Integration).

Once configured, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is ready to receive replicated employee master data from SAP SuccessFactors EC through the SAP Integration Suite. The Communication Arrangement provides the inbound service URLs, which must be stored in the corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow) of the SAP Integration Suite to establish end-to-end communication.

To create the arrangement, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the “Communication Arrangements” app.

Select Communication Arrangements

 Then click on “New” to create a new Communication Arrangement.

Create New Communication Arrangement

Choose SAP_COM_0001 as the Communication Scenario.

Assign Communication Scenario

Select Communication Scenario

After that, further setting up configurations needs to be done. Therefore, the before created Communication System will be attached.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Select Communication System))

In our scenario, no additional configuration (e.g. cost center replication, address, or payment information) was required, so these fields remained empty.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Additional Properties))

The Inbound Communication User is automatically populated once the corresponding Communication System is selected. At the same time, the Inbound Service provided the service URL used as the receiver endpoint in the iFlow configuration of the SAP Integration Suite.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Inbound Services)

 3.2.4 Monitoring of Replication Scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Accurate and timely replication of employee data from SAP SuccessFactors is essential for Incident Management and other EHS processes. Any replication failure can prevent incidents from being assigned to the correct person or role, impacting compliance and operational safety. SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides the Message Dashboard app to monitor replication scenarios. Before using it for the JB1 integration scenario, recipients must be assigned in the “Assign Recipients to Users“ app.

Configuration Steps:

1. Open the "Assign Recipients to Users" app in the SAP Fiori Launchpad.

Select Assign Recipients to Users

 2. Verify that your user is assigned with the following details:

  • Namespace: /WFD
  • Recipient Name: WFD_WORKER_INTEGRATION
  • Message Type: Application Error or Technical Error

Check if Recipients are assigned to User

 3. If your user is not listed, add a new entry using your User ID and the details above.

Add New User and assign New Recipient

Enter User ID

Assign Recipients to User

Once recipients are assigned, the Message Dashboard displays all relevant replication messages – including errors, warnings, and successfully processed records – allowing early detection and resolution of integration issues.

Note: To reprocess messages directly from the Message Board, the user must have the SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR business role assigned. Without this role, reprocessing is not authorized.

Message Dashboard Overview:

Select Message Dashboard

The Message Dashboard provides a consolidated view of all replication messages for the JB1 scenario:

  • The calendar view indicates daily status (green = no errors, red = errors occurred).
  • Messages can be filtered by date range for detailed analysis.
  • The result list summarizes processed messages per interface (e.g., WFD_WORKER/1), including counts of warnings, technical errors, and successful replications.

This monitoring ensures transparency and operational reliability by allowing administrators to quickly identify and resolve replication issues before they impact EHS processes.

Message Dashboard Overview

3.3 Integration Package Implementation in SAP Cloud Integration

3.3.1 Integration Credentials Configuration

In the previous step (chapter 3.2.3), we created Communication Arrangements in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to enable inbound communication from external systems. These arrangements ensure that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud can safely receive employee master data from the SAP Integration Suite.

Within the SAP Integration Suite, the Integration Flow (iFlow) must authenticate against two endpoints:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud – for employee master data via SAP Integration Suite
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC – which triggers the replication process when called by the iFlow

For communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Basic Authentication was used. The credentials of the Inbound Communication User from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must therefore be maintained as Security Material within the SAP Integration Suite. This configuration ensures that the integration flow can authenticate securely when transmitting data between the two systems.

Set up Security Material for Authentication against SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

For communication with SAP SuccessFactors, the iFlow uses OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion, which requires creating a Security Material entry with a Key Pair in the SAP Integration Suite. This setup ensures secure authentication whenever the iFlow retrieves data from SAP SuccessFactors.

The highlighted process flow below illustrates where SAP SuccessFactors is triggered by the SAP Integration Suite:

JB1 Process (Maintain Employee Master Data)

For a detailed step-by-step guide on setting up OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion and Security Material in SAP Integration Suite, refer to this SAP Community Blog.

3.3.2 Copying Integration Packages

SAP provides preconfigured integration content for scope item JB1 as part of the standard best-practice setup. This allows a straightforward configuration process, since you can simply copy the predefined package into your own workspace. For our scenario, the following integration package was required:

  • SAPSuccessFactorsEmployeeCentralIntegrationwithSAPS4HANAEmployeeData

The package can be found in the Discover section of the SAP Cloud Integration workspace. Once copied, it includes all necessary Integration Flow (iFlow) required for employee master data replication between SAP SuccessFactors EC and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

In the next step, we will configure these iFlows to establish the data exchange process.

Search for Integration Package in SAP Integration Suite

Copying the Integration Package

 

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.3 “Copying Integration Packages” (pages 55–56) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.3.3 Integration Package Configuration

Configuring Employee Master Data Replication Integration Flow (iFlow) for Initial Full Load:

After copying the integration package into your workspace, the first configuration step is the Initial Full Load. This ensures that all relevant employee master data from SAP SuccessFactors EC is replicated into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud before any delta update occurs.

Why this is important: Accurate and up-to-date employee master data is essential across all EHS use cases, as it ensures that roles, responsibilities, and organizational structures are consistently reflected in safety and compliance processes. This is particularly critical for Incident Management, where incidents must be linked to the correct employees and supervisors. Without a complete initial load, subsequent data updates cannot be processed reliably.

Key Actions:

1. Set the Timer to Run Once: In the iFlow configuration, choose Run Once for the initial execution. This triggers a one-time full replication of all employee master data.

iFlow Settings for Timer

Note: After the initial load is complete, switch the timer to Schedule to Recur for delta replication.

Why is this needed? Because the initial load only runs once. If you leave the timer unchanged, no further updates will be replicated. By switching to a recurring schedule, you enable delta replication, which keeps employee data continuously up to date.

2. Configure Receivers: Next, open the iFlow and click “Configure”. Two recipients must be set up:

iFlow Select Configure

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Receiver: Use the details from Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001. While Certificate-based Authentication is recommended for productive environments, Basic Authentication can be used for test setups. Enter the service URL of SAP_COM_0001 as the address of the receiver. 

Set up Receiver for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • SAP SuccessFactors Receiver: Configure OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion for secure API calls. The address can be taken from the JB1 setup instructions (page 57). The Credential Name here is the same as the Security Material created in chapter 3.3.1.

Set up Receiver for SAP SuccessFactors

 3. Adjust Core Parameters

  • Set Initiate_Full_Load = TRUE for the initial run (reset to FALSE afterwards)
  • Define Company Codes and Workforce Type
  • Set the Full_Transmission_Start_Date to include all relevant employee records

Once deployed, the iFlow performs a complete replication of employee master data. This step establishes the foundation for all ongoing delta updates and ensures that EHS processes consistently reference the correct workforce context.

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.4.1 “Configuring Employee Master Data Replication iFlow for Initial Full Load” (pages 56–59) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

Configuring Employee Master Data Replication Integration Flow (iFlow) for Delta Replication:

After the initial full load has established the basic dataset in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the next step is to enable delta replication. This ensures that any changes in SAP SuccessFactors, such as new hires, terminations, or updates to employee information, are continuously synchronized with S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Why this is important: Delta replication plays a key role in keeping employee master data current across all EHS use cases. Accurate and timely workforce is essential not only for Incident Management, but also for other processes like Risk- or Emission-Management, where employee roles and organizational responsibilities drive compliance and reporting accuracy. Without a delta replication, the system would remain static after the initial load, leading to outdated information and potential inconsistencies. By enabling the delta replication, updates are processed incrementally, reducing system load and improving overall efficiency.

Key Checks before Deployment:

To activate delta replication, ensure the following settings are applied (as mentioned in the initial load configuration):

  1. Timer: Set to Schedule to Recur with an appropriate frequency (e.g., every 10 minutes between 00:00 and 24:00).
  2. Parameter: Set Initial_Full_Load = FALSE to switch from full load to incremental updates.

All other configuration steps remain the same as for the initial load.

Result: Once deployed, the iFlow performs incremental updates instead of a full replication, ensuring that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud always reflects the latest employee master data for EHS and related business processes.

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.4.1 “Configuring Employee Master Data Replication iFlow for Delta Replication” (pages 60 – 61) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.3.4 Reset Existing Delta Sync Configuration

In exceptional situations, it may become necessary to reset the delta synchronization configuration. This option is designed to reinitialize the replication process by clearing the stored delta markers, allowing the system to fetch data as if it were the first replication cycle.

When is a reset relevant?

  1. Correction of inconsistencies: If previous delta runs failed or resulted in incomplete updates, a reset ensures that all changes are captured.
  2. Testing and validation: For scenarios where a fresh replication cycle is required without performing a complete system reset.
  3. Troubleshooting: When resolving integration issues that cannot be addressed through standard delta processing.

By resetting the configuration, the system retrieves data from the earliest defined point, ensuring completeness. However, this approach should be applied with caution, as it can lead to significant data volumes being processed again.

How can the Reset be performed?

  1. Open the SAP Cloud Integration Web UI of your SAP Cloud Integration tenant and choose “Monitor” (under Design) from the top-level menu on the left.
  2. In the “Manage Stores” block, choose the “Variables” tile. The available variables are displayed in the Global Data Store.
  3. To reset a replication scenario, delete the corresponding variable(s) from this list by choosing the “Delete” button next to the variable(s). The delete button for each variable is on the right side of the variable table in column “Actions”. The table below specifies the variable name(s) of the variable(s) which needs(s) to be deleted to reset the delta sync configuration for the replication scenario / corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow).

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.5 “Reset Existing Delta Sync Configuration” (pages 69 - 70) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.4 End-to-End Monitoring of Employee Master Data Replication

Monitoring is a critical part of ensuring that employee data replication runs smoothly across all systems involved in the JB1 integration scenario. Accurate employee data is the foundation for all EHS processes, as many scenarios – such as incident tracking, risk assessments, and regulatory reporting – depend on reliable workforce information. Inaccurate or incomplete replication can disrupt these processes and impact compliance or operational efficiency.

3.4.1 Monitoring Across Systems

Employee Master Data Replication involves three layers:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Inbound Monitoring): As described in chapter 3.2.4, inbound replication is monitored using the Message Dashboard (AIF Monitoring). This allows administrators to review message statuses and reprocess failed messages if required.
  • SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (Source Monitoring): In SAP SuccessFactors, replication activity can be monitored using the SFAPI Audit Log, which displays outbound replication calls and related processing information. While this functionality is available, it is not covered in detail here.
  • SAP Integration Suite (Middleware Monitoring): The SAP Integration Suite ensures that data flows correctly between SAP SuccessFactors and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Monitoring focuses on the integration flow status, message processing, and error handling within the middle layer.

3.4.2 Monitoring in SAP Integration Suite

SAP Integration Suite provides several tools to track and manage integrations flows:

1. Navigate to Manage Integration Content: Navigate to Monitor > Manage Integration Content to verify that the Integration Flow (iFlow) for employee replication is deployed and running. The status Started indicates that the flow is active.

Navigate to Manage Integration Content

 2. Monitor Message Processing: Under Monitor Message Processing, you can view detailed logs for executed messages.

Navigate to Monitor Message Processing

This view shows whether each message has been successfully processed or if any errors occurred.

Example of successfully completed Message Processing

3. Message Status Overview: The Message Status Overview aggregates statistics across all processed messages, including completed, failed and retried executions. This provides a consolidated view of the integration scenario over a selected timeframe and supports quick identification of patterns or recurring issues.

Message Status Overview

(These steps correspond to chapter 6 “Monitoring of Replication Scenarios” (page 71) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

 

4. Lessons Learned

Implementing JB1 for employee integration in SAP EHS Public Cloud provided several key insights that are even important for similar projects:

1. Employee Integration is Mandatory: Accurate workforce data is the foundation for EHS processes. Without it, Incident Management cannot correctly identify the involved people, assign responsibilities, or ensure compliance.

2. Initial Load is Critical: A successful initial replication establishes the baseline for all subsequent updates. Any errors at this stage can lead to inconsistencies throughout the system.

3. Delta Replication ensures Timelines: Regular updates are essential to reflect organizational changes such as new hires or role adjustments. Without delta replication, the system remains static and operational risks increase.

4. Reset Delta Sync is a Fallback, not a Routine Step: This option is useful for correcting inconsistencies or re-initializing data during testing. However, it should be applied cautiously due to the potential for large data volumes.

5. Monitoring is Essential for Operational Reliability: Continuous monitoring of replication flows prevents disruptions. Tools like AIF monitoring in SAP S/4HANA and Execution Manager in SuccessFactors proved invaluable for early error detection.

6. Authentication Strategy Matters: While Basic Authentication is acceptable for demos or test environments, certificate-based authentication is strongly recommended for production to ensure security standards.

7. Organizational Data Alignment is Key: Mismatches between legal entities and company codes were identified as a common source of replication errors. Early validation avoids downstream issues.

8. Demo vs. Production Considerations: Simplifications used in demos (e.g., Basic Auth) needs to be adapted for production environments to ensure compliance and robustness.

9. Optional Data Can Become a Blocker: Missing or incorrect optional fields, such as bank details, can prevent successful replication. These fields should be validated early in the process.

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

Acknowledgements

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.

A special thank you goes to:

  • @Westphal 
  • @qkroiss 
  • @asutoshmaharana2326 
  • @kanwal_singh
  • @Suraj_Ashray1 

 Their contributions were instrumental in shaping the content of this blog post. I am truly grateful for their collaborations and support.

Integrating SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook

Part 3: Integration of Business Partner & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)

Table of Contents:

  • 1. Why is this Integration required?
  • 2. Prerequisites
  • 3. Technical Integration
  • 3.1 Communication User & Communication System Setup for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • 3.1.1 Create Inbound Communication User
  • 3.1.2 Create Communication System
  • 3.2 Business Partner Integration
  • 3.2.1 Communication Arrangement for Integration Scenario SAP_COM_0008
  • 3.2.2 Integrate Business Partner Data from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • 3.3 Product Integration
  • 3.3.1 Communication Arrangement for Integration Scenario SAP_COM_0009
  • 3.3.2 Integrate Products from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • 3.4 Configure Message Monitoring SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • 4. Lessons Learned
  • 5. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series – each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side – Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Why is this Integration required?

Integrating Business Partner and Material master data from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) into SAP EHS Public Cloud is a foundational step for enabling core EHS processes, particularly in Emissions Management. Instead of maintaining these master data objects locally within SAP EHS Public Cloud, the system relies on harmonized and validated Business Partner and Material data coming from the corporate master data governance layer. This ensures that supplier information, responsible persons, material properties, and classification attributes remain consistent across the enterprise.

Accurate and up-to-date Business Partner and Material data is essential in Environment, Health & Safety (EHS), as many analytical and reporting steps in Emissions Management depend on correctly maintained master data. Examples include assigning responsible Environmental Managers, linking sampling activities to suppliers or contractors, and using material-specific characteristics (e.g., heating values, emission factors, composition) as inputs for emission calculations.

In other words: Without integrated Business Partner and Material data, SAP EHS Public Cloud cannot reliably calculate emissions, assign responsibilities, or produce compliant environmental reports.

Architectural Approach - Scope

The highlighted section of the architectural diagram illustrates the scope relevant to this blog post - focusing on the integration of Business Partner and Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Reference to User Scenario (C) – Emissions Management

In part 1 “Introduction & Overview”, the User Scenario (C) – Emissions Management at Mike Machineries clearly illustrated why this integration is required:

Scenario Step

Why Business Partner & Material Integration Matters

The Environmental Manager prepares the annual emissions monitoring plan

The Environmental Manager must exist as Business Partner with up-to-date organizational data to be assigned as the responsible person for monitoring and reporting activities.

An Environmental Technician collects samples and records operational data

The technician must be identifiable as a Business Partner to ensure accountability, traceability, and proper assignment of sampling tasks.

Supplier-provided material data is used to support emission factor calculations

Material master data – such as composition, heating values, or supplier relationships – must be accurate and synchronized from MDG to ensure correct calculation of emission factors.

SAP EHS aggregates emission data and calculates quarterly NOx emissions

Material attributes and Business Partner assignments form essential input for compliant and reproducible emission calculations.

A deviation is detected, triggering an investigation

The system must determine responsible persons (Business Partner) to initiate corrective actions and assign follow-up tasks.

A Corrective Action Plan is defined and assigned

Task assignments require valid Business Partner information to ensure that responsible roles receive, process, and complete corrective actions.

Findings are shared with Sustainability and Operations teams

Consistent organizational Business Partner data ensures that notifications and reporting reach the correct stakeholder groups across sites.

Without integrated Business Partner and Material data, the system would not be able to:

  • Identify responsible persons (Environmental Manager, Technician, etc.)
  • Use complete and reliable material attributes in emission calculations
  • Track corrective actions or investigation responsibilities
  • Produce compliant and auditable emissions reports

Note: Although employees such as the Environmental Manager or the Environmental Technician could technically be replicated from SAP SuccessFactors, this alone is not sufficient for Emissions Management. The SAP SuccessFactors integration delivers Workforce Persons, which are used for people-related EHS processes (e.g., workflows, incident reporting, assignments). Emissions Management, however, requires full Business Partner master data – including organizational roles, supplier relationships, and external parties – that SAP SuccessFactors does not provide. These Business Partners are essential for material classification, supplier-dependent emission factors, regulatory reporting, and responsibilities that are not limited to internal employees.

This makes the integration of Business Partner and Material master from SAP MDG into SAP EHS Public Cloud a mandatory prerequisite for configuring Emissions Management.

Note: When implementing Emissions Management as shown in the User Scenario, ensure that the relevant scope item – 4XD – Emissions Management – is activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Central Business Configuration (CBC). This activation enables the Emissions Management processes and configuration in SAP EHS Public Cloud so that the replicated Business Partner and Material master data can be used for monitoring, calculating, and reporting emissions.

While this integration is mandatory for Emissions Management, it is equally relevant for other EHS use cases such as Risk Management or Incident Management. In these scenarios, consistent master data ensures reliable assignment of responsibilities, correct categorization of materials, and accurate process execution. Across the organization.

Therefore, in the following section, we will take a closer look at the general setup of the Business Partner and Material data integration between SAP MDG and SAP EHS Public Cloud.

 

2. Prerequisites

To successfully integrate Business Partner and Material Master data from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled. These ensure that master data replication works seamlessly and support EHS processes such as Emission Management.

To successfully set up this integration scenario, the following prerequisites must be in place:

Tenant Provisioning:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant
  • SAP MDG system should be available as the source system.

Administrator Access: Ensure administrator users exist in both systems:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: The administrator should have the template role of SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR assigned to allow creation of communication users, systems, and arrangements.
  • SAP MDG for replication framework setup.

Scope Item Activation:

While this section focuses on the setup required for Emission Management, the same integration scenario also enables other EHS functionalities like Incident Management and Risk Management. For these processes, the corresponding scope items described in part 1 must be activated:

  • 3FP – Incident Management
  • 54A – Risk Management

In our scenario for Emission Management following scope items were activated:

  • 1RO – Master Data Integration
    • Purpose: Provides the technical foundation for master data replication, including communication scenarios for Business Partner (SAP_COM_0008) and Material Master (SAP_COM_0009).
    • Why: Without 1RO, the integration cannot be configured because the required APIs and replication models are not available.
  • 4XD – Emissions Management (only if Emission Management is in scope)
    • Purpose: Enables emission-related processes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.
    • Why: Business Partner and Material Master data serve as the backbone for emission sources and organizational assignments.

Data Requirements:

  • Legal entities in SAP Material Master Governance (MDG) must match the Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Mismatches will lead to replication failures).

Cloud Connector Setup:

To establish secure and reliable communication between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the On-Premise SAP MDG system, the SAP Cloud Connector must be properly configured for this integration scenario.

  • Register the SAP MDG system in the Cloud Connector UI and ensure that the connection is active and reachable.
  • Define a virtual host and port in the Cloud Connector. This virtual host will later be referenced when creating the Communication System in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.
  • Ensure  that the SCC Location ID is maintained to link the correct connector instance.

 

3. Technical Integration

This section describes the practical implementation of the master data integration based on the predefined 1RO – Master Data Integration scope item. It outlines how Business Partner and Material Master data are replicated from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and highlights the key configuration areas involved in the process.

The 1RO scope item provides the standard integration scenario for master data replication and supports related data flows that are essential for EHS processes such as Incident Management, Risk Management, and Emission Management. Accurate and consistent master data is crucial for these use cases, as organizational structures, business partners, and material information form the foundation for compliance and operational processes.

Therefore, this section focuses on the Business Partner and Material Master integration processes, which serve as the backbone for all subsequent EHS configurations.

Key 1RO Configuration Areas:

  • Communication User and Communication System setup for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • Business Partner Integration (SAP_COM_0008)
  • Product Integration (SAP_COM_0009)
  • Configure Message Monitoring SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

For detailed documentation, please refer to the official 1RO content in the SAP Process Navigator.

1RO Setup Instructions as PDF

3.1 Communication User & Communication System Setup for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration

The integration scenario in this chapter enables the replication of Business Partner and Material Master data from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

This is achieved by using the predefined communication scenarios delivered by SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:

  • SAP_COM_0008 – Business Partner Integration
  • SAP_COM_0009 – Product Integration

Both scenarios form part of the activated scope item 1RO – Master Data Integration, which provides the APIs and replication models required for master data exchange between SAP MDG and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

In our setup, SAP_COM_0008 and SAP_COM_0009 were both assigned to one shared Inbound Communication User and one shared Communication System. The differentiation between scenarios is handled within the Communication Arrangement, where scenario-specific service endpoints and authentication settings are maintained.

3.1.1 Create Inbound Communication User

The Inbound Communication User is required for authenticating inbound calls from SAP MDG to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. We created a dedicated user (e.g. MDG_IN) using the “Maintain Communication Users” app in the SAP Fiori Launchpad.

Select Maintain Communication User

 If no suitable user exists, a new one must be created by choosing “New”.

Select New Communication User

 The username and password for Basic Authentication can be defined freely.

Illustration of our Communication User - Overview

Once created, the system automatically structures the user view, showing assignments to Communication Systems and Arrangements (added in later steps).

Illustration of our Communication User - Assigned Communication System & Arrangements

 3.1.2 Create Communication System

The Communication System represents the technical connection between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the external SAP MDG system. It includes critical configuration information such as: Hostname, authentication method, inbound/outbound communication users, technical identifiers used for secure system-to-system communication.

Note: Unlike the JB1 employee replication in part 2 (chapter 3.2), which connected SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to SAP Integration Suite, the 1RO master data scenario connects SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud directly to the SAP MDG On-Premise system. This scenario is SOAP-based and does not involve middleware. Therefore, SAP MDG ats as the external Business System in the Communication System setup.

If no applicable Communication System exists, a new one must be created via the “Communication Systems” app.

Select Communication SystemsSelect New Communication System

Enter a System ID and System Name referring to the SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) tenant and proceed with the set up.

After creating the new Communication System entry, additional configuration details must be maintained – including Technical Data, User for Inbound Communication and User for Outbound Communication. These parameters define how SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud connects with the external SAP MDG tenant. For comprehensive configuration guidance, refer to the 1RO setup instructions.

Communication System Setup - Technical Data 1

Note: As we are connecting a cloud system to an on-premise system, the SAP Cloud Connector needs to be added to the Communication System. If your on-premise system is currently not linked via any Cloud Connector, please refer to your SAP BASIS admin. Once the SAP MDG On-Premise system is added as mentioned before, the Cloud Connector then provides a secure tunnel and enables the use of virtual host names and its corresponding virtual port, which can be viewed in the SAP BTP Cockpit via Connectivity > Cloud Connectors. These values must be maintained as Host Name and Port in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Communication System.

Additionally, the SCC Location ID must be maintained in the Communication System to ensure the correct connector instance is used. As the SCC Location ID is only visible in the UI of the Cloud Connector, please refer to your BASIS admin to get the SCC Location ID. For further information you can have a look in the SAP Help Portal.

For the Business System, we added our SAP MDG tenant and configured the Logical System using the SAP MDG system‘s runtime URL. It is important to enter the runtime URL without the „HTTPS:/“ prefix as the protocol is handled separately during the communication setup.

Because we are using Basic Authentication, all other advanced communication settings – including RFC Settings, OAuth 2.0 Settings, Event Exchange Infrastructure, Remote SQL Access, and Identify Provider configurations – were intentionally left empty or set to offline, as they are not required for our case.

Communication System Setup - Technical Data 2

Communication System Setup - Identify Provider

For the Inbound Communication User, we selected the one created in the previous step.

The Outbound Communication User does not necessarily come from the “Maintain Communication Users” app. It can be any technical user in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system with the required authorizations for outbound communication. In productive scenarios, it is recommended to use a dedicated technical user for this purpose.

Communication System Setup - Users for Inbound & Outbound Communication

If any Communication Arrangements are assigned (will be explained in later sections), they will be visible within this Communication System.

Communication System Setup - Overview of assigned Communication Arrangements

3.2 Business Partner Integration

3.2.1 Communication Arrangement for Integration Scenario SAP_COM_0008

In the Communication Arrangement, the previously created components (Communication User and Communication System), have been linked within the integration scenario SAP_COM_0008. This arrangement consolidated the technical connection and authentication setup by combining the Communication System (representing the external MDG system) with the appropriate Inbound and Outbound Communication Users. Once configured, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is prepared to receive replicated Business Partner master data from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG).

The Communication Arrangement also provided the inbound service URL required for the MDG replication and enables secure, consistent data exchange as part of the 1RO scope item.

To create the arrangement, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the “Communication Arrangements” app.

Select Communication Arrangements

 Then click on “New” to create a new Communication Arrangement.

Create New Communication Arrangement

 Choose SAP_COM_0008 as the Communication Scenario.

Assign Communication ScenarioSelect Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0008

After that, further setting configurations needs to be done. Therefore, the before created Communication System will be attached.

Add Communication System to Communication Arrangement

Take note of the value maintained in the field “Own SAP Cloud System” (see screenshot below). This value is required when configuring the external MDG system, where it must be entered in fields such as System Instance ID, Business System ID, or IDoc Logical System ID during the setup of the corresponding integration settings.

In our case, the fields under “Additional Properties” remained empty.

Own SAP Cloud System in Communication Arrangement

Based on the selected Inbound Communication User, the system automatically derives the user for this Communication Arrangement. The Inbound Services listed in this section can remain unchanged. Their respective Service URLs are generated automatically from the API base URL ad the service-specific path.

Communication Arrangement Setup - Inbound Communication User

For Outbound Communication, the system automatically derives the User Name from the assigned Communication System.

By default, all Outbound Services are set to “Active”. The predefined Service URL and Basic Type can remain unchanged, as these values are generated automatically.

Since our integration scenario replicates Business Partner data from the on-premise SAP MDG system to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, we follow the guidelines described in chapter 3.1.5 of the scope item in the 1RO setup instructions, page 16. According to these guidelines, all Outbound Services must be set to “Inactive”, except for:

  • Business Partner – Send Confirmation from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Client
  • BP Relationship – Send Confirmation from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Client

These two services must remain active so that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud can send confirmation messages back to the source system (SAP MDG) after successful processing. This ensures proper synchronization attempts within the Data Replication Framework.

Communication Arrangement Setup - Required Outbound Services

3.2.2 Integrate Business Partner Data from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

This section focuses on the Business Partner replication setup based on the recommendations of chapter 3.1.5 of the 1RO setup instructions, beginning at page 16. Since the required Outbound Services and Service URLs were already outlined in chapter 3.2.1, we continue here with the configuration of the Inbound Services within Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0008.

To begin the integration setup, the WSDL/Service Metadata for the following Inbound Services from the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system:

  • Business Partner – Replicate from Client to SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Business Partner Relationship – Replicate from Client to SAPS/4HANA Cloud

Download WSDL Service Metadata from the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0008

Upload WSDL in SAP MDG - SOAMANAGER

In the on-premise SAP MDG system, navigate to SOAMANAGER. According to the 1RO setup instructions, chapter 3.1.5 – Procedure – sub chapter 4 - page 18, you must choose between a central or decentral configuration approach. In our scenario, we used the decentral configuration.

Navigate to SOAMANAGER in SAP MDG On-Premise System

Note: To enable dynamic receiver determination, the Business Partner web service uses service groups in SOAMANAGER. Consequently, logical ports for the service consumer must not be created manually; instead, they must be generated automatically based on the integration scenario. This requires a WSDL-based configuration.

De-Central Configuration Approach:

We selected the decentralized configuration approach because it provides the flexibility required for our system landscape. While SAP MDG remains the primary source for master data, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud may also perform validations or localized adjustments. A decentralized setup is typically preferred when multiple systems need to manage master data independently, ensuring agility and avoiding reliance on a single central system.

Ensure that the Central Configuration switch is set off for this setup. You can verify this under: Technical Administration > SAP Client Settings > Central Configuration.

De-Central Configuration Approach

After that, we need to upload the before downloaded WSDL/Service Metadata to the on-premise SAP MDG system. Therefore, navigate to Tools > WSDL Upload

Uploading WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER - Overview

Create a new entry with the appropriate Name, Description, and WSDL Base with the selected radio button “Via File”, and upload the first WSDL file. Repeat this step for the second WSDL file as well.

Uploading WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER

Note: The WSDL typically contains several protocol and authentication alternatives. By default, WS-RM and HTTPBasic are selected. If another option is preferred (e.g., SAP-RM), the WSDL must be adjusted prior to upload by removing unneeded alternatives.

Create Entries in Service Registry:

Navigate to Service Registry > Publication of External WSDL.

Publish Uploaded WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER - 1

Choose the uploaded WSDL file and follow the instructions of the 1RO setup instructions. The steps you can find in chapter 3.1.5 De-Central Configuration Approach – Create Entries in a Service Registry, page 21.

Publish Uploaded WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER - 2

 Chapter 3.1.5 - Create Entries in a Service Registry - Page 21

Ensure that in step 7 of the above shown steps, the Own SAP Cloud System is entered in the System Name field, and the corresponding API-URL (as Host Name) is taken from the communication arrangement SAP_COM_0008, as described in chapter 3.2.1.

Publish Uploaded WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER - 3

 Own SAP Cloud System in Communication Arrangement

When repeating the WSDL publication step for the BusinessPartnerRelationship WSDL, select the existing Physical System that was created in the previous step.

Publish Uploaded WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER - 4

Create Profile:

When integrating via SOAP services, the WSDL only defines the interface. The security profile ensures secure communication by specifying:

  • Authentication (User ID/Password)
  • Transport Security (secured communication)
  • No IBC determination for simplified setup

This profile is referenced by provider systems to enforce consistent security settings for all service calls. Navigate to Technical Administration > Profiles

 

Create Profile in SOAMANAGER - 1

Create the new user as specified above. We created a DEFAULT_PROFILE in our scenario.

Create Profile in SOAMANAGER - 2

Create a Provider System:

The provider system links SAP MDG to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for SOAP-based integration. Navigate to Technical Administration > Provider Systems

Create Provider System in SOAMANAGER - 1

Create the Provider System as mentioned in the 1RO setup instructions. The steps you can find in chapter 3.1.5 De-Central Configuration Approach – Create a Provider System, page 21-22.

Chapter 3.1.5 - Create a Provider System - Page 21-22

Use the same Name as maintained in the Own SAP Cloud System of the SAP_COM_0008 Communication Arrangement, and assign the profile created in the previous step.

Create Provider System in SOAMANAGER - 2

For WSDL Access, if no system appears in the value help, select the service registry SR_LOCAL and remove this system from the value help. Ensure that the WSIL Service is deactivated.

Create Provider System in SOAMANAGER - 3

According to WSDL Documents select Basic Authentication and enter the user credentials of your MDG user. Ensure that the Tolerant Search option is enabled under Search Granularity.

Create a Provider System in SOAMANAGER - 4

In the creation step, select Retrieve Business Applications. The system will automatically generate an entry for the business application. Complete the changes afterwards.

Create Provider System in SOAMANAGER - 5

Create logon data:

Creating logon data ensures secure authentication for SOAP communication between SAP MDG and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. It centralizes credential storage and links them to service definitions to support reliable and secure data replication. To configure this, navigate to: Service Administration > Logon Data Management

Create Logon Data in SOAMANAGER - 1

In the Maintenance tab, create a new user if none exists and select User/Password or X.509 as the authentication method. Enter the user of the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system that was created as the Inbound Communication User and maintain the corresponding password.

Create Logon Data in SOAMANAGER - 2

In the Assignment tab, proceed the remaining steps described in the . The steps you can find in chapter 3.1.5 De-Central Configuration Approach – Create Logon Data, page 22.

Chapter 3.1.5 - Create Logon Data - Page 22

Create Integration Scenario Configuration:

This step consolidates all previously configured settings into an executable integration scenario and generates the logical ports required for SOAP-based replication. For that, navigate to Service Administration > Local Integration Scenario Configuration.

Create Integration Scenario in SOAMANAGER

As all required settings required for this step are mentioned in the previous steps, you can follow the remaining steps of . You can find them in chapter 3.1.5 De-Central Configuration Approach – Create Integration Scenario Configuration, page 22.

Chapter 3.1.5 - Create Integration Scenario Configuration - Page 22

Configuration in Data Replication Framework:

Since the SAP MDG system is operated as an on-premise system in our scenario, the configuration within the Data Replication Framework (DRF) is carried out using the DRFIMG transaction. As a result, two configuration steps are required.

  • Configuration of Communication (Target) System:

Navigate to Define Custom Settings for Data Replication > Define Technical Settings > Define Technical Settings for Business Systems.

Define Technical Settings for Business System

On the first level, the Business System and Logical System must be maintained. These entries must match the corresponding settings in SOAMANAGER. Optionally, an RFC Destination can be specified (e.g., <Business System>_IDOC) if IDoc-based communication is intended.

On the second level, the relevant Business Objects are selected. For this scenario, the following objects have been configured: 147 – Business Partner, 986 – Business Partner including Relationships, 194 – Product (used for product integration). The output mode has been set to D – Direct Output. Note: Business Object 194 is not part of the Business Partner but is used exclusively for product integration.

Configuration of Communication (Target) System - 2

On the next level, the corresponding communication channels for replication via Services were assigned to Business Objects 147 and 986, as illustrated below.

Configuration of Communication (Target) System - 3

  • Configuration of Replication Model: After defining the technical settings for the target system in DRF (Business System, Logical System, and communication channels), the next step is to create and configure the replication model.

Navigate to Define Custom Settings for Data Replication > Define Replication Models.

Define Replication Models

Create a new replication Model. Therefore, select New Entries on the first level and provide a name and description for the model. This model determines which business objects will be replicated to the target system.

Define Replication Model - 1

Select the new entry and navigate to Assign Outbound Implementation on the second level. For the Business Partner replication, use Outbound Implementation 986_3 (Business Partner including Relationships), give a description and choose Communication Channel Replication via Services.

Define Replication Model - 2

After this step, select the new Outbound Implementation 986_3 and navigate to Assign Target Systems for Replication Model/Outb. Impl. on the third level. Enter the previously configured target system.

Define Replication Model - 3

At Assign Outbound Parameter we can define, how many records will be collected into a bulk message. Therefore, you can use the outbound parameter PACK_SIZE_BULK. A recommended value for this parameter is 100.

Define Replication Model - 4

After the replication model is defined, save your changes, select the replication model and choose Activate. Note that this step is required, as replication can only be executed after successful activation.

Configuration of Value Mapping

During Business Partner integration, certain code lists differ between SAP MDG and SAP S/4Public Cloud. To ensure seamless replication, these values must be mapped so that the target system correctly interprets the data sent from the source system.

Examples where value mapping is required for code lists:

  • BP groupings (DTEL MDG_FND_NR_INTERVAL_BP_GRP_COD)
  • Account groups (TABL MDG_FND_BP_MAINT_PRF_CODE)
  • Region codes (TABL MDG_FND_REGION_CODE)
  • Pricing procedure (DTEL KALKS)

Note: Although value mapping is primarily maintained in the on-premise system, certain entries may still need to be created in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud using the “No Mapping” indicator to avoid unnecessary mapping attempts during inbound processing.

In our scenario, we also executed the value mappings described above. The example below illustrates how Account Group value mappings are maintained in the code lists. You must decide in which system (SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud or SAP MDG) the mapping should be maintained. In our case, the mapping was performed in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Before maintaining value mappings, the relevant code lists must be assigned to the respective business systems and elements. This ensures that the replication framework knows which code list is applicable. To perform this activity, open the SAP Fiori Launchpad as Business Expert and navigate to Assign Code Lists to Elements and Systems.

Assign Code Lists to Elements & Systems

In our scenario, we assigned several code lists (such as Tax Types, Account Groups, and BP Groupings) to our MDG business system. After assignment, we defined value mappings to harmonize internal and external codes – for example, mapping the internal tax type to external code MWST. Next, navigate to the “Maintain Value Mapping” app and select Position.

Select Position in Maintain Value Mapping

Enter the Object Type and Global Data Type that were assigned as code lists to the corresponding elements and system.

Enter parameter selection

 Select the relevant Value Mapping Field.

Select Value Mapping FieldAssigned Code Lists

Select the assigned code list and navigate to Define Value Mapping. Here, specify how the source system codes (SAP MDG) corresponds to the target system codes (SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud). For example, the external tax type “MWST” from MDG is mapped to the internal code 01 in the cloud system. This ensures consistent interpretation of data during replication.

Define Value Mapping

This example is provided for reference only to demonstrate how value mappings can be created in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Depending on your project requirements, you may need to maintain additional mappings accordingly.

3.3 Product Integration

3.3.1 Communication Arrangement for Integration Scenario SAP_COM_0009

To extend the integration beyond Business Partner data and establish the product integration between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the SAP MDG system, we created an additional Communication Arrangement using scenario SAP_COM_0009, which provides the required communication services for product replication.

Therefore, as before, choose “New” in the “Communication Arrangements” app and select the communication scenario SAP_COM_0009.

Select Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0009

As described in chapter 3.2.1, take note of the value maintained in “Own SAP Cloud System”, as it is required for configuring the external MDG system. This value will be used in the target integration systems for parameters such as System Instance ID, Business System ID, and IDoc Logical System ID.

Next, select the Communication System previously created for this scenario (“MDG”).

After selecting the Communication System, all related information, such as the Inbound Communication User, and the Service URLs of the outbound services – will be automatically populated.

Assign Communication System & Own SAP Cloud System

For the additional properties, we selected Product Number Harmonization = 1 to ensure that product numbers from SAP MDG remain consistent in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system. By selecting setting, products are replicated with the same number as in the SAP MDG system. If the product number already exists in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the system updates the existing product rather than creating a duplicate. If the number is already used for a different product, the replication fails. In our scenario, no mapping was required because MDG was used as the leading system.

Select Value for Product Number Harmonization

In our scenario, inbound services were the most relevant because they enabled the replication of product data from SAP MDG to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Outbound services, in contrast, were not required for the main data flow.

The only outbound service we kept active was “Product Master – From S/4HANA Cloud to Client”, which is necessary to send a confirmation back to the source system (SAP MDG) after successful processing. All other outbound services can be set to “inactive” to avoid unnecessary communication and reduce complexity.

Required Outbound Services

3.3.2 Integrate Products from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

The transfer of Product Master data from the on-premise SAP MDG system to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud follows a similar process to the steps described in chapter 3.2.2, with only minor adjustments specific to the product integration.

Since the product master data replication is handled via the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0009, a different inbound service is used for this scenario.

The inbound service used for this scenario is: ProductMDMBulkReplicateRequest_In

This service also includes the service group MDM_PRD_REPLICATE_REQ, which will be required later during the configuration steps in SOAMANAGER within the on-premise SAP MDG system.

Download WSDL Service Metadata for Product Integration

Configuration in Data Replication Framework:

  • Configuration of Communication (target) System:

Due to the DRF customizing in the SAP MDG transaction DRFIMG, the same target system is referenced, using Business Object 194 (Product) together with the Key Mapping as part of Key Harmonization. To configure this, navigate to: Custom Settings for Data Replication > Define Technical Settings > Define Technical Settings for Business Systems

On the first level, select the Business System and navigate to the communication channel configuration for Business Object 194 (Product). Because Key Mapping is also used for the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0009, it must additionally be configured here in the target system communication settings, as shown below.

Configuration of Communication (Target) System for Product Integration

  •  Configuration of Relocation Model:

This follows the same logic described in chapter 3.2.2. For product replication, the outbound implementation 194_3 (Product Master Data) is used.

In our scenario we used for the assigning of the outbound implementation the same replication model as for the Business Partner. Assign the same Target System as for the Business Partner. Optionally you can assign the outbound parameter PACK_SIZE_BULK which will define how many records will be collected into a bulk message.

Configuration of Replication Model for Product Integration

Value Mapping for Products:

Value mapping for product-related data follows the same principle as the Business Partner. Below is an example of value mappings already maintained in the on-premise SAP MDG system for Mechanical Engineering.

Value Mapping for Products in SAP MDG On-Premise System3.4 Configure Message Monitoring SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Accurate and timely replication of Business Partner and Product Master Data from SAP MDG on-premise to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is essential for Emission Management processes. Any replication failure can lead to incorrect assignments of emission sources, roles, or responsibilities, which may impact compliance with environmental regulations and operational safety. SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides the “Message Dashboard“ app to monitor replication scenarios. Before using it for the 1RO integration scenario, recipients must be assigned in the “Assign Recipients to Users“ app.

Configuration Steps:

1. Open the “Assign Recipients to Users“ app in the SAP Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad.

Select Assign Recipients to Users2. Verify that your user is assigned with the following details:

Namespace

Recipient Name

Message Type

Overview

Technical User

/CMDBP

CMD_BP

Application Error or Technical Error

Select the checkbox.

Select the checkbox

/CMDPR

CMD_PRODUCT

Application Error or Technical Error

Select the checkbox.

Select the checkbox.

/MDMKM

MDM_KEY_MAPP ING

Application Error or Technical Error

Select the checkbox.

Select the checkbox.

Required Recipient User Subscriptions for Monitoring - 1

If your user is not listed, add a new entry using your User ID and then assign the details of the table shown above.

Once recipients are assigned, the Message Dashboard displays all relevant replication messages – including errors, warnings, and successfully processed records – allowing early detection and resolution of integration issues.

Note: To reprocess messages directly from the Message Board, the user must have the SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR business role assigned. Without this role, reprocessing is not authorized.

Message Dashboard Overview:

Select Message Dashboard

The Message Dashboard provides after this setup a consolidated view of all replication messages for the 1RO scenario:

  • The calendar view indicates daily status (green = no errors, red = errors occurred).
  • Messages can be filtered by date range for detailed analysis.
  • The result list summarizes processed messages per interface (e.g. /CMDBP), including counts of warnings, technical errors, and successful replications.

This monitoring ensures transparency and operational reliability by allowing administrators to quickly identify and resolve replication issues before they impact.

Message Dashboard Overview

 

4. Lessons Learned

Implementing 1RO for Business Partner and Product integration – from the SAP MDG On-Premise system to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud – provided several valuable insights that are highly relevant for similar integration projects.

1. Separate Replication Models Are Mandatory in DRF: Even though Business Partner and Product replication steps look similar, each requires its own replication model in DRFIMG because outbound implementations (986_3 vs 194_3) are object specific. Trying to reuse the same model can cause conflicts.

2. Service Groups Are Crucial for Dynamic Routing: The concept of service groups in SOAMANAGER is essential for Business Partner and Product replication. They enable dynamic receiver determination and simplify configuration. Ensure WSDL-based configuration is used to generate logical ports automatically.

3. Value Mapping Is Often Overlooked: Differences in code lists (e.g., BP groupings, account groups, material types) between MDG and S/4HANA Public Cloud can cause replication failures. Plan value mapping early and verify mappings in both systems.

4. Cloud Connector Setup is required for integrations from an On-Premise System into Cloud: Incorrect virtual host or missing SCC Location ID in the Communication System often leads to connectivity issues. Validate these settings before proceeding with SOAMANAGER configuration.

5. Monitoring Setup Is Critical for Operational Reliability: Assign recipients in the “Assign Recipients to Users” app before using the Message Dashboard. Without this, replication errors will not be visible to the right users, delaying troubleshooting.

6. Consistency in Product Number Harmonization: For Product replication, enabling “Product Number Harmonization” in the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0009 prevents duplicate products and ensures updates instead of new creations. This setting is often missed.

7. Test with Small PACK_SIZE_BULK First in the DRF configuration: Start with a smaller bulk size (e.g., 10) during initial testing to simplify error analysis. Increase to the recommended 100 only after successful initial runs.

8. Documentation Alignment with 1RO: Always cross-check with SAP’s official 1RO documentation. Minor deviations (e.g., service names, WSDL variants) can lead to integration failures.

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.

A special thank you goes to:

  • @Westphal

  • @Suraj_Ashray1 

 Their contributions were instrumental in shaping the content of this blog post. I am truly grateful for their collaborations and support.
