Integrating SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook

Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

Table of Contents:

  • 1. Why is this Integration required?
  • 2. Prerequisites
  • 3. Technical Integration
  • 3.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration
  • 3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • 3.2.1 Create Communication User
  • 3.2.2 Create Communication System
  • 3.2.3 Create Communication Arrangement
  • 3.3 SAP Integration Suite Configuration
  • 3.3.1Establishing the Event Queue for On-Premise Triggers
  • 3.3.2 Integration Credential Configuration
  • 3.3.3 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup - Equipment
  • 3.3.4 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup – Functional Locations
  • 3.4 Monitoring
  • 3.4.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise
  • 3.4.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • 3.4.3 SAP Integration Suite
  • 4. Lessons Learned
  • 5. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series – each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side – Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Why is this Integration required?

Integrating Functional Locations and Equipment master data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP EHS Public Cloud is a foundational step for enabling core EHS processes such as Risk Management, Incident Management, and Emissions Management. Instead of maintaining asset-related data manually within SAP EHS Public Cloud, the system relies on validated Plant Maintenance (PM) master data coming from the customer’s existing ERP landscape. This ensures that all structures, machines, and technical objects involved in EHS processes remain consistent, reliable, and audit-proof across the enterprise.

Accurate and up-to-date Functional Location and Equipment data is essential because many EHS processes depend on a clear understanding of where work is performed and which technical objects is affected. This includes:

  • Identifying the exact machine or installation involved in an incident
  • Linking hazards to the correct technical asset in Risk Assessments
  • Performing control inspections and assigning follow-up actions
  • Ensuring asset-specific exposure, material usage, or emission characteristics are correctly evaluated
  • Centralizing reporting across operational sites based on real asset hierarchies

In other words: Without integrated Functional Location and Equipment data, SAP EHS Public Cloud cannot reliably assess risks, evaluate hazards, track incidents, or produce compliant operational reports.

Architectural Approach - Scope

The highlighted section of the architectural diagram illustrates the scope relevant to this blog post – focusing on the integration of Functional Locations and Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Reference to User Scenario (B) – Risk Management

In part 1 “Introduction & Overview”, the User Scenario (B) – Risk Management at Mike Machineries (chapter 2.1.1) demonstrated why this integration is required:

Scenario Step

Why Plant Maintenance (PM) Integration Matters

A supervisor identifies a hazard in the chemical handling area

The hazard must be assigned to the correct Functional Location to ensure accurate traceability and reporting.

An Industrial Hygienist conducts a risk assessment

Equipment properties (e.g. ventilation units, storage cabinets, extraction systems) must be available from SAP PM to evaluate exposure and technical conditions.

Mitigation actions are defined

Some mitigation measures depend on technical object (e.g., upgrading ventilation, replacing equipment, updating signage).

A control inspection is performed

The inspection must reference the exact equipment or Functional Location where the mitigation is implemented.

Residual risk is recalculated

The correct asset hierarchy ensures that results are assigned to the right operational area or machine.

Results are shared with operations teams

Consistent Functional Location data ensures findings reach the correct plant, work center, or technical area.

Without integrated Functional Locations and Equipment, the system would not be able to:

  • Assign hazards or incidents to the correct asset
  • Trace risk assessments and inspections to the real technical environment
  • Evaluate machine-specific conditions and exposures
  • Monitor the effectiveness of mitigation actions at asset level
  • Ensure accurate reporting across operational areas and sites

Note: When implementing Risk Management as demonstrated in the user scenario, ensure that the relevant scope item 54A – Health & Safety Management (for Risk Management) is activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Central Business Configuration (CBC). This activation enables the Risk Assessment and Control Inspection processes in SAP EHS Public Cloud so that synchronized Functional Locations and Equipment master data can be used consistently.

While this integration is mandatory for Risk Management, it is equally relevant for other EHS use cases such as Incident Management or Emissions Management. In all these processes, consistent asset data provides the foundation for identifying affected areas, assessing technical conditions, and enabling accurate regulatory reporting.

 

2. Prerequisites

To successfully integrate Plant Maintenance data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via the SAP Integration Suite, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled:

Tenant Provisioning:  

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant 
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise tenant (with activated Plant Maintenance)
  • SAP Integration Suite tenant (Cloud Integration + Event Mesh)

Administrator Access: 

Ensure administrator users exist in all three systems: 

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: The administrator should have the template role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR assigned to allow the creation of communication users, systems, and arrangements. 
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise: Users with access to the SPRO are required.
  • SAP Integration Suite: A User with admin rights for Event Mesh and iFlow deployment is required.

Scope Item Activation:  

Following scope items need to be activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:

  • 4HH – Reactive Maintenance (mandatory for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud communication scenario regarding the inbound services for Equipment and Functional Locations).
  • 54A – Health & Safety Management (required for Risk Management scenario).

Activated OData Services in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System:

  • API_EQUIPMENT and API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION active in SAP Gateway (check via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE).

Event Mesh Instance:

  • Provisioned by SAP BTP with service key available (for AMQP connection).

These prerequisites ensure that the integration of Plant Maintenance – specially changes made in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system – operates smoothly and reliably, thereby supporting EHS processes such as Risk Management.

 

3. Technical Integration

This section provides an overview of the technical integration required to replicate Plant Maintenance master data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for EHS processes.

The integration scenario builds on the activation of the scope item 4HH – Reactive Maintenance, which delivers the necessary inbound services for Equipment and Functional Locations in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. These objects form the foundation for EHS capabilities such as Risk Management, Incident Management, or Emissions Management.

The process shown in this integration scenario is event-driven. This means, whenever changes occur to Plant Maintenance master data, such as Equipment or Functional Location in the On-Premise system, these updates are automatically replicated to the Public Cloud. This approach keeps both systems aligned without manual steps or scheduled batch jobs, ensuring that asset information is always current.

Keeping master data synchronized between both systems is critical for effective Risk Management because risk assessments and mitigation strategies depend on accurate details about assets and their locations.

By ensuring that updates flow seamlessly between systems, organizations can make informed decisions and maintain compliance across their EHS processes.

Key Configuration Areas: 

  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration 
  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration 
  • SAP Integration Suite Configuration
  • Monitoring

3.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration

As this integration scenario for Functional Locations and Equipment is event driven, the creation of channels was required in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system to publish business events to the SAP Integration Suite via Event Mesh.

In this context the channels define the protocol (AMQP), destination (Event Mesh service key), and topic space.

Outbound bindings specify which event topics (e.g., sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/*) are sent. This ensures that changes in Functional Locations or Equipment trigger the corresponding iFlows in the SAP Integration Suite.

Channels can be created by navigating to SPRO > ABAP Platform > Enterprise Event Enablement > Administration > Chanel Connection Settings > Manage Channels and Parameters.

Therefore, we created the channel IS_INTERNAL_EVENTMESH which uses the AMQP Protocol.

Event Channels in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

After creating the channel, we added two outbound bindings to define which event topic should be published.

  • sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/*
  • sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/*

Added Outbound Bindings to created Event Channel

This configuration ensures that business events for Functional Locations and Equipment are reliably published from the on-premise system to SAP Integration Suite via Event Mesh, enabling event-driven iFlows without the need for polling.

3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration

In addition to setting up SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must also be configured to receive employee master data via the SAP Integration Suite. 

For this purpose, a Communication Arrangement is required to enable secure data exchange between the systems. In this scenario, the predefined Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395 – Asset Management Master Data Integration is used.

By activating and configuring this Communication Arrangement enables the necessary inbound API services, allowing the SAP Integration Suite to push employee data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. 

To create the Communication Arrangement, we need to create a Communication User as well as a Communication System that will be assigned to the related Communication Arrangement.

3.2.1 Create Communication User

In this integration scenario, an Inbound Communication User was created in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (e.g., user OPN_IN). This user was used for Basic Authentication in the Communication Arrangement, and its credentials were securely stored in the Security Material of the SAP Integration Suite to enable a safe connection between the systems. 

Select Maintain Communication Users

To create the Inbound Communication User in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, log in to the Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the app “Maintain Communication Users”.  

Select "New"

If no suitable user exists, select “New” to create one.

Created Communication User - General Data

The username and password for Basic Authentication can be freely defined. 

Related Communication System and Arrangements

Once created, the system automatically structures the user view, showing assignments to Communication Systems and Arrangements (added in later steps). 

3.2.2 Create Communication System

The Communication System is a necessary component for the Communication Arrangement. If you have already set up a Communication System for the S/4HANA On-Premise system, you can use it for the Communication Arrangement. Please note that the previously created Communication User must be assigned to this system for the following steps. Furthermore, no additional system-level settings (regarding outbound communication) are necessary, as the communication scenario SAP_COM_0395 only uses inbound services.

If no related user exists, you can create a new one as follows: Navigate to the S/4HANA Public Cloud app “Communication Systems”.

Select Communication Systems

Select “New”.

Select "New"

Enter a System ID and System Name referring to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise tenant and proceed with the set up. 

Creating new Communication System

Select Inbound Only as the communication scenario SAP_COM_0395 only uses Inbound Communication.

Select Inbound Only

Assign the previously created Communication User.

Assign Communication User

3.2.3 Create Communication Arrangement

The final step in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud configuration is to bind the previously created components  (Communication User and Communication System) within the Communication Arrangement (SAP_COM_0395 – Asset Management Master Data Integration). 

Once configured, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is ready to receive replicated Plant Maintenance master data (e. g. Functional Locations or Equipment) from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system through the SAP Integration Suite. The Communication Arrangement provides the inbound service URLs, which must be stored in the corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow) of the SAP Integration Suite to establish end-to-end communication. 

To create the arrangement, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the “Communication Arrangements” app. 

Select Communication Arrangements

Then click on “New” to create a new Communication Arrangement. 

Select "New"

Select Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0395

Choose SAP_COM_0395 as the Communication Scenario.

Choose Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0395

After the creation of the Communication Arrangement the before created Communication System will be attached. Note that the corresponding Communication User will be determined automatically.

Communication System and User

The Inbound Service of the Communication Arrangement provides us then the Service URL, that will be used as the receiver endpoint in the iFlow configuration of the SAP Integration Suite.  

Required Inbound Services

3.3 SAP Integration Suite Configuration

In this integration scenario we used the SAP Integration Suite as the middleware layer to enable secure and reliable data exchange between the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Therefore, the SAP Integration Suite is responsible for retrieving Plant Maintenance master data (such as Functional Locations and Equipment) from the On-Premise system and delivering it to the Public Cloud using event-driven integration flows.

Since there is no pre-delivered integration package available for this scenario, we created two custom iFlows to handle the replication of Functional Location and Equipment data. Both iFlows follow a similar structure in terms of processing logic; however, they differ in the endpoints used for communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the On-Premise system respectively.

Custom Integration Package for this Scenario

3.3.1 Establishing the Event Queue for On-Premise Triggers

The first step in this implementation is to create an Event Queue in SAP Event Mesh using the Message Client. This queue serves as the trigger point for event-driven integration. When a change occurs in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system (such as an update to Functional Locations or Equipment), an event is published to the queue.

The iFlow will be later subscribed to the Event Queue and use the event as a trigger to start processing. Once triggered, the iFlow calls the related API in the On-Premise system to retrieve the full master data for the affected object. This design ensures that updates are replicated to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud in near real-time, keeping both systems synchronized.

Note: The SAP Event Mesh – Message client is typically provisioned by the BASIS administrator. If you have no existing Message Client, please refer to your BASIS team.

Once the message client was set up, navigate to it inside the SAP Integration Suite > Configure > Event Mesh.

Navigate to Message Client in SAP Integration Suite

Since our EHS scenario relates to Functional Locations and Equipment, we have created two separate event queues here. Therefore, select Create.

Select "Create"

Enter a name for the new Event Queue(e. g. opn.equipment). You can keep the remaining fields as default.

Queue Settings for opn.equipment

Then navigate to Subscriptions and select Create.

Select "Create"

Two Topic Subscriptions were required within the Event Queue Details for the Equipment:

  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/Created/v1
  • <message-client-prefix>/de/ce/sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/Changed/v1

Note: Regarding the Subscription, the message-client-prefix will be typically provisioned by your BASIS team. The remaining part of the respective topic names of the Equipment event is SAP standard and can be viewed in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in the tab Event References Event References | Equipment Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Repeat this step also for the Functional Location. Therefore again, enter a name for the new event queue (e. g. opn.FuncLoc). The following subscriptions are needed for this event queue:

  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/Changed/v1
  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/Created/v1

The Functional Location events for the Functional Locations can be found in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in the tab Event References Event References | Functional Location Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

3.3.2 Integration Credential Configuration

Within the SAP Integration Suite, the created integration flows (iFlows) must authenticate against three endpoints:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud – to push the synchronized data to the cloud system.
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise – to retrieve Functional Location and Equipment data
  • SAP Event Mesh – to consume events via AMQP protocol and trigger the integration process.

Note: To ensure secure authentication for each endpoint used by the iFlow, a dedicated Security Material object was created for every connection. In our demo environment, Basic Authentication was sufficient; however, for productive landscapes, certificate-based authentication is required to meet security standards and comply with enterprise policies.

For communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Basic Authentication was used in this scenario. The credentials of the Inbound Communication User from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must therefore be maintained as Security Material within the SAP Integration Suite. This configuration ensures that the integration flow can authenticate securely when transmitting data to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Security Material

The Security Material that was used for communication with the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, was created in a similar way using Basic Authentication, based on the credentials of the On-Premise user. Note that the On-Premise user will be provided by your SAP BASIS team.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Security Material

For the Event Mesh Security Material that enables communication with SAP Event Mesh, OAuth 2.0 was used for authentication. Therefore, enter the Token Service URL, Client ID and Client Secret, which are provided by the service key of your SAP Event Mesh Instance in SAP BTP Cockpit.

SAP Integration Suite - Event Mesh Security Material

3.3.3 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup - Equipment

Regarding the iFlows we will setup the Equipment Integration iFlow first. Therefore, create the iFlow with a corresponding name, set SAP S/4HANA as Sender and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as Receiver.

Sender and Receiver Setup for Equipment iFlow

The integration flow starts with an AMQP connection to SAP Event Mesh. This connection allows the iFlow to subscribe to event queues and consume messages whenever Functional Location or Equipment changes occur in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system. The AMQP protocol ensures reliable, event-driven communication between the systems and acts as the trigger for the subsequent OData calls.

Therefore, connect the Receiver with the Start Message using the Adapter Type AMQP with Websocket as Transport Protocol.

First iFlow Step - AMQP Adapter Setup

The General tab inside the Adapter can stay as default. In the Connection tab you need to add a Host, Port and Path of the Event Mesh Service Key. You will find this Service Key in the Event Mesh Instance of your SAP BTP Cockpit. For Authentication use OAuth 2.0 and add the associated Security Material for Event Mesh (created in the previous step) as Credential Name.

AMQP Adapter Connection Setup

AMQP Adapter Connection Setup

In the Processing tab, add the event queue name for the equipment.

Assign Event Queue opn.equipment to AMQP Adapter

The incoming event message from SAP Event Mesh is delivered in JSON format. Since subsequent processing steps and OData calls require XML, the JSON to XML Converter transforms the payload accordingly. In this scenario, namespace mapping is disabled because the JSON structure does not include namespaces that need to be preserved in the XML output. The remaining parts of the Converter can stay as default.

JSON to XML Converter

After the conversion to XML, we added a Content Modifier. This Content Modifier is used to extract specific values from the XML structure and store them as Message Header and Exchange Properties.

Content Modifier Setup - General

In the Message Header tab, the Content Modifier reads values from the XML payload using XPath and sets them as message headers. In our example, we set the SAP_ApplicationID header with the Functional Location value found at /root/data/Equipment in the XML.

Content Modifier Setup - Message Header

In the Exchange Property tab, the Content Modifier creates two properties by extracting values from the XML payload using XPath: p_eventType from /root/type and p_equipmentno from /root/data/Equipment. These properties are later used to dynamically build the OData request URL for the GET call to the on-premise system.

Content Modifier Setup - Exchange Property

Next, we set a Request Reply with the name Get Equipment Data. This enables us to get the data via OData Adapter from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

In the Connection tab of the OData adapter, we define how the integration flow connects to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system. In our example, the address consists of the virtual host and port provided by the SAP Cloud Connector, followed by the OData service path /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_EQUIPMENT/, which is the standard endpoint for the Equipment API in SAP Gateway. The proxy type is set to “On-Premise”, and the Location ID refers to the configured Cloud Connector destination (can be found in the Master Instance for your Cloud Connector in the SAP BTP Cockpit > Logged in into your Subaccount > Connectivity > Cloud Connectors). Regarding the authentication, was used with the on-premise related Security Material.

Note: We leveraged an existing SAP Cloud Connector configuration to securely connect the SAP Integration Suite to the on-premise system without exposing the real backend host.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Connection

Note that the API_EQUIPMENT is activated in your on-premise system. You can check this via the transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE and searching for the API_EQUIPMENT OData Service.  

In the Processing tab, we configured a GET operation to the Resource Path Equipment. Therefore, click Select.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing

Choose Connection Source Remote. The fields will be automatically filled with the provided data in the Connection tab. Then click on Step 2. If the connection is configured correctly, we will configure the operation and entities here.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 1

Then select the operation “GET”, the Select Entity “Equipment”, the Sub Levels 1 and choose “Select All Fields”.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 2

To retrieve only the changes for the specific Equipment Number, apply a filter on the property ${property.p_equipmentno} that was set in the Content Modifier earlier. Filter for the ValidityEndDate as shown below.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 3

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 4

After retrieving the equipment data from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, we ensured with a message mapping step that the structure and fields of the incoming data match with the expected values for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. For our related message mapping we used a predefined mapping resource (/MM.mmap) created in the iFlow to transform the received data to the expected structure.

Message Mapping 1

Message Mapping 2

After completing the mapping as required for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Equipment Inbound Service, we set a new Request Reply with an OData V2 adapter to the receiver endpoint of the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System

In the Connection tab add the inbound service URL for the Equipment provided by the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395 in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Inbound Service URL for Equipment in Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395

Choose Proxy Type Internet and add your Security Material that was created for communication with the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Basic Authentication.

As we want to send the structure which the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system expects, we need to create new processing details for this OData Adapter. Therefore, choose the Processing tab and navigate to Select.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing

Choose again the Connection Source Remote. The required details to connect with the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system will be shown here again automatically after the previous details in the Connection tab have been configured. Then navigate to Step 2.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 1

Now choose the Operation Post, Entity Equipment, Sub Levels 1 and Select All Fields. For the Post operation no filters are required.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 2

Note: The iFlow also shows an Exception Subprocess. You can perform this after the implementation of the iFlow is finished. In our scenario we let the Exception Subprocess empty.

Exception Subprocess

3.3.4 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup – Functional Locations

The iFlow for the Functional Locations was similar in architecture, with small changes.

Created iFlow for Functional Location

For the AMQP Adapter at beginning of the iFlow, the event queue for Functional Location was used.

Used Event Queue in iFlow Funcional Location

According to Content Modifier > Message Header, the used Source Value was /root/data/FunctionalLocation.

Content Modifier in iFlow Functional Location - Message Header

In the Exchange Property tab of the Content Modifier, we changed the second line entry to the Name p_functionallocation and its Source Value to /root/data/FunctionalLocation.

Content Modifier in iFlow Functional Location - Exchange Property

According to the Get Functional Location Data that will perform a GET operation to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, we used the OData Service for “API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION” with the root address /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION/. Note again that the API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION is activated in your on-premise system. You can check this via the transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE and searching for the API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION OData Service. 

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

In the Processing tab navigate to Select and go to Step 2 (As the fields required for the system connection will be filled automatically).

Choose the Operation and Select Entity as shown below with Sub Level 1 and Select All Fields.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration

Regarding the query, we were only filtering for FunctionalLocationLabelName equals ${property.p_functionallocation}.

The Message Mapping now needs to be performed for the Functional Location. Therefore, we used again the Resource /MM.mmap but now with a new mapping.

Message Mapping 1

Message Mapping 2

For the last OData Adapter sending the transformed Functional Location data from the SAP Integration Suite to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Inbound Service URL for the Functional Location was used in the Address Field of the Connection Details.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System - Connection

Inbound Service URL for Equipment in Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395

According to the Processing details, the connection to the system will be again filled automatically. Then Navigate to Step 2 and choose the Select Entity as well as the Operation as shown below. Choose again Select All Fields.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration

3.4 Monitoring

Monitoring is a critical part of ensuring that event-driven integration for EHS Risk Management runs reliably across SAP S/4HANA (Public Cloud & On-Premise) and the SAP Integration Suite. Accurate and timely event processing is essential because many risk-related processes depend on these events. Missing or delayed events can lead to incomplete risk assessments, gaps in safety measures, and potential compliance violations.

The Monitoring can be performed at all three involved systems.

3.4.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

Regarding the Outbound Events that are sent from the on-premise system to the SAP Integration Suite, you can navigate to SPRO > ABAP Platform > Enterprise Event Enablement > Monitoring > Monitor Event Queues.

If any failures for the Outbound Events occur, they can be analyzed here.

Event Monitor in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

3.4.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, monitoring focuses on API communication rather than event queues. The primary tool that can be used here is the “OData Error Log” app, which provides detailed error messages for failed OData requests. This is essential for troubleshooting issues when SAP Integration Suite sends data to the Public Cloud system.

OData Error Log in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System

3.4.3 SAP Integration Suite

SAP Integration Suite provides several tools to track and manage integrations flows. As already described already in the part 2 you can therefore navigate within the SAP Integration Suite to Monitor > Overview > Manage Integration Content. Here you can select your respective iFlow (e.g. “Functional Location Integration in between SAP S4HANA and SAP S4HANA Cloud”) and select Monitor Message Processing.

Manage Integration Content for Functional Location iFlow

This view provides a clear overview of the processing status for each message, indicating whether it was completed successfully or if any errors occurred during execution.

Monitor Message Processing

By selecting Message Status Overview on the upper right corner,  statistics will be shown across all processed messages, including completed, failed and retried executions. This provides a consolidated view of the integration scenario over a selected timeframe and supports quick identification of patterns or recurring issues. 

Message Status Overview

 

4. Lessons Learned

Implementing this integration scenario via the scope item 4HH for Plant Maintenance data (such as Functional Locations or Equipment) from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provided several valuable insights that are highly relevant for similar integration projects.

1. Event-Driven Integration Ensures Real-Time Accuracy: Using SAP Event Mesh with AMQP is critical for keeping Functional Location and Equipment data synchronized. Batch jobs cannot guarantee timely updates for EHS processes like Risk Management.

2. Validate OData Services Early: Missing activation of API_EQUIPMENT or API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION in the on-premise system is a common root cause for iFlow failures. Always check via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE before starting.

3. Topic Naming in Event Mesh Requires Precision: Incorrect prefixes or typos in topic subscriptions will block event processing entirely. Always cross-check against SAP Business Accelerator Hub references.

4. Message Mapping Is Compliance-Critical: Ensure that Equipment and Functional Location data is transformed correctly for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Missing mandatory fields can lead to incomplete risk assessments and reporting gaps.

5. Monitoring Is Essential for Operational Reliability: Event-driven integration depends on timely message processing. Use monitoring tools in all three systems (SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP Integration Suite, and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud) to detect and resolve issues early.

6. Plan Authentication Strategy Upfront: Basic Authentication works for demos, but production environments require certificate-based authentication. Delaying this switch can cause project delays and security risks.

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.

A special thank you goes to:

  • @Westphal

Their contributions were instrumental in shaping the content of this blog post. I am truly grateful for their collaborations and support.

entry.title: Introducing User-Defined Reports (UDR) in SAP Responsible Production and Design
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of SAP Responsible Design and Production as of November 25, 2025.

SAP Responsible Design and Production released User-Defined Reports (UDR) this year, extending its reporting framework with a fully configurable, customer-driven approach developed to support customers with the ever-evolving and growing number of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) regulations. With UDR, users can now create customized EPR reports for packaging based on their unique business and compliance needs.

UDR also enables SAP and in the near future, content partners, to offer templates for new EPR schemes that customers can adapt in their own systems, to help them expand EPR reporting quickly. This new functionality aims to ease the burden of managing reporting obligations across multiple markets.

This blog post explains the background and motivation for this feature, provides a sneak peek into the key functionalities used to create country-specific EPR report categories, and highlights how this enhancement improves flexibility and extensibility for EPR data reporting.

Background

As EPR regulations continue to expand globally, businesses face increasing complexity in how they manage compliance. Regulations vary not only from country to country but often overlap or undergo changes over time, making it challenging for customers to keep up while relying on predefined reporting structures.

SAP Responsible Design and Production has long supported customers in meeting EPR requirements through SAP-provided report categories that are preconfigured to match the packaging obligations in countries such as Spain, Italy, and the UK. While these reports have served as a reliable foundation, there is a growing need for a more flexible and more nuanced reporting approach.

Companies increasingly require a way to:

  • Adapt quickly to new or changing legislation
  • Reuse rules and fee structures across similar reporting schemes or Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs)
  • Consolidate data from diverse sources
  • Customize reporting logic based on their specific business context

This is exactly why SAP introduced User-Defined Reports (UDR): to provide customers with an agile, scalable, and future-ready foundation for building report categories aligned with regulatory logic, business context, and compliance requirements.

Key Capabilities of UDR

User-Defined Reports bring together several powerful capabilities that allow customers to design report categories tailored to their specific regulatory and operational needs. 

1 Build the Structure of Your Report

Responsible Organizations

EPR schemes are managed by Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs). Many countries operate with more than one PRO, each offering different fee structures or criteria. In Spain, for example, Ecoembes manages general packaging, while Ecovidrio is responsible for glass packaging. UDR allows users to:

  • Attach multiple PRO-specific fee tables to the same report category
  • Reuse the same report fractions and rules across PROs
  • Avoid creating separate report categories for each PRO (as long as their rules do not conflict)

This gives customers flexibility in markets where several PROs coexist.

Report Fractions

Report fractions are the foundational building blocks of a UDR report. They represent the categories into which packaging is classified according to national legislation or PRO requirements. Fractions can be created and named based on the exact fee structure of the country or PRO, ensuring a one-to-one alignment with how fees are calculated.

Report Fraction Groups

To support cleaner structuring and reporting layouts, fractions can be combined into report fraction groups. These groups help users organize related fractions (for example, separating paper-related fractions based on usage or the brand) and simplify both calculation and reporting outputs.

2 Control the Logic Behind Your Report

Filters for Included Packaging

Filters add a foundational layer of control by allowing users to exclude packaging that should not be part of a particular report or fee calculation. They can be applied at multiple levels within the report category setup and help ensure that only relevant data is included based on the requirements of each EPR scheme.

Together with calculation rules, filters help shape a reporting outcome that aligns with legislative and business requirements.

Calculation Rules

Report calculation rules form one of the most powerful elements of UDR.
They determine which packaging is included in a report and how quantities and fees are calculated, giving customers the flexibility to reflect the exact compliance logic required by each market. Because calculation rules can combine multiple conditions, attributes, and data sources, they enable users to shape reporting logic precisely around their business and regulatory needs, making this capability central to the flexibility that UDR offers.

Calculation rules come with a wide collection of rule examples, expressions and functions that can be leveraged to fit the users’ reporting requirements.

Logistic Processes

Logistic processes represent the specific movements of products or packaging that are relevant for a country’s EPR legislation, such as domestic sales, imports, exports, or other flows defined by the market. In UDR, users can select which logistic processes apply to their report category and combine them with filters or calculation rules. This allows the user to reflect only the movements that are obligated in that country, ensuring the report aligns with how packaging enters or leaves the market.

 

3 Capture Sustainability-Driven Criteria

Ecomodulation

Many EPR schemes increasingly use ecomodulation to reward sustainable packaging choices. UDR allows users to set ecomodulation criteria based on the relevant EPR scheme and incorporate them into calculation rules. This further enables fees to be calculated according to the required ecomodulation rules. To learn more about ecomodulation, visit the SAP Responsible Design and Production community page for a detailed blog on this topic, releasing soon.

Recyclability

UDR also integrates recyclability outcomes directly into reports. When setting up a report, recyclability guidelines can be selected and applied, to be used in calculation rules when needed. This allows recyclability insights to feed directly into the report structure, supporting countries where recyclability affects fees or criteria (such as the bonus/malus payments on EPR fees in France). Users can either upload date manually via Excel or integrate with a partner of their choice.

4 Test and Validate Your Setup

Test Configuration

With test configurations, users can simulate the reporting outcome for one to ten products. This enables quick validation of rule logic, filters, and fee calculations before generating the full report, ensuring accuracy and reducing iteration time.

5 Templates

Not all EPR schemes have the same level of complexity. To ease the effort in building highly detailed report categories using UDR, Templates have been introduced; preconfigured starter packs that provide the structure and logic needed to get started, which can be adapted to fit the user’s requirements.

Currently, SAP provides Templates for US-Colorado, US-Oregon, and Denmark, with more to follow. Keep an eye on the SAP Responsible Design and Production Roadmap for upcoming additions.

Customer Response & Early Results

Customers who tested UDR shared strong and practical feedback, including:

“Only 25% of time and effort is required for using UDR compared to manual efforts.” (from consumer products company)

“First we were skeptic, but now we like using UDR.” (from food processing company)

These early insights reflect the impact of a flexible, user-driven reporting approach. To see this in a real-world setting, please check out our recent webinar, Navigating EPR regulations in the United States: Act Now! where our customer shares their experience with UDR.

What’s Next

UDR was shaped with direct input from customers, and this collaboration will continue. As EPR regulations evolve, SAP will focus on enhancing UDR, improving the configuration experience, and supporting reporting needs across markets.

One of the planned enhancements is around AI-assisted features that could make it easier to create calculation rules logic and work more efficiently with UDR using natural language.

Where to Learn More and Act!

To further explore UDR, detailed documentation with practical examples and additional guidance on calculation rules  available. You can also access a guided, step-by-step walkthrough showing how to create a UDR here.  We will continue to publish updates there as UDR evolves.

For broader product information on SAP Responsible Design and Production, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release. 

To take the next step, you can request a demo or contact us for a consultation. For additional regulatory context and practical guidance, you may also want to download our white paper on managing EPR regulations and plastic taxes.

entry.title: 🔎 Research Community Spotlight: SAP @ KD²lab Karlsruhe
entry.content:
SAP and KIT Expand Research Partnership

Prof. Dr. Alexander Mädche, head of the Human-centered Systems Lab.

SAP and the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT) are longstanding partners in academic and research endeavors. In 2019, this partnership was further institutionalized through a comprehensive framework contract for joint research initiatives, paving the way for further collaboration. 

A recent initiative exemplifies the growing partnership between SAP and one of Germany's most prestigious technical universities: the research collaboration with the Human-Centered Systems Lab (h-lab).

Led by Prof. Dr. Alexander Mädche, the h-lab research group organized its first "Research and Innovation Symposium on Human-centered AI for Sustainable Business" in November 2025, in collaboration with Dr. Norbert Frech-Koppenhagen and Christian Boos from SAP. The event took place at Karlsruhe Decision & Design Lab (KD²lab), a DFG-funded experimental lab located in the heart of Karlsruhe.

 

Business Software meets Behavioral Science

Dr. Julia Seitz registering a study participant at KD2lab (copyright: KIT/Amadeus Bramsiepe).

The KD²lab at KIT is one of the world's largest computer-based behavioral science experimental laboratories. 

40 soundproof computer cubicles, climate-controlled experimental rooms, and high-resolution biosignal measurement equipment (including eye tracking, ECG, and EEG) enable researchers to capture neuro- and psychophysiological processes under controlled conditions.

Dr. Julia Seitz is Research Team Lead for two research streams at h-lab: Agentic Enterprise Systems and Biosignal-Adaptive Collaboration Systems. She combines psychological theories and behavioral economics approaches in her experimental research on human-centered information systems design.

Focusing on collaboration in teams of humans and AI agents, Dr. Seitz is particularly interested in how adaptive and agentic information systems in the workplace impact users. In her research, she combines qualitative and quantitative empirical methods with real-time processing of biosignal data to explore how agentic software design can improve outcomes and collaboration.

 

AI for Sustainability

In the collaborative project "Agentic Information Systems for Sustainability" with SAP, Dr. Seitz is working alongside Anna Sommer, SAP PhD student at KIT, to explore a crucial question: How can generative AI agents and humans work together optimally to drive sustainable business practices?

SAP PhD student Anna Sommer.Using human-centered AI design approaches and hands-on experimental research, the team is investigating the dynamic interplay between humans and generative agents, identifying which forms of interaction deliver the most impactful results.

"The project's ambition is to develop AI systems that truly complement human expertise rather than replace it: Systems that enhance rather than diminish critical thinking, enable more efficient resource management, and strengthen both ecological and social sustainability," says Anna Sommer. 

In her current study, she is investigating how the use of AI agents influences cognitive processes—particularly critical thinking—and whether these effects differ between different AI agents. To do this, participants first complete a critical thinking test with the help of an AI agent. In a second part of the study, this test is replaced with a realistic task from the field of sustainability management requiring critical thinking. This part takes place in the KD²lab and is supplemented by additional measurement methods such as eye tracking.

Ultimately, Anna Sommer's goal is to develop guidelines for AI agents that actively foster critical thinking rather than hinder it—an ability that is becoming increasingly vital for businesses striving for sustainable success.

 

💬 Get in Touch with the SAP Research Community

Below is an overview of the planned blog series – each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side – Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Introduction: Why Extensibility Matters in EHS Implementations

Implementing SAP Environment, Health & Safety (EHS) in the Public Cloud provides customers with a powerful set of standard capabilities across EHS functionality such as Incident Management, Risk Management, or Emissions Management. However, real-life EHS processes often include country-specific regulations, industry-dependent reporting obligations, and customer-individual workflows that cannot always be covered by the standard product alone. This is where extensibility becomes a critical success factor.

From our project experience, we see that nearly every EHS implementation requires selected adaptations – whether to incorporate local legal requirements, enrich analytics, adjust incident forms, or create custom validations. With SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and SAP EHS, such enhancements must follow SAP’s clean-core principles, meaning they must be implemented using the officially supported extensibility technologies.

This blog post provides a clear, practical overview of the extensibility options available for SAP EHS in the Public Cloud and demonstrates how they can be applied to real-world scenarios.

1.1 What You Can Expect from This Blog Post

In this part, we outline the extensibility landscape for EHS Public Cloud and guide you through:

  • Which extensibility options exist in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • How they apply specifically to EHS use cases
  • Which BAdIs are available and when to use them
  • Concrete examples for extensibility
  • Best practices based on our project experience

The aim is to give implementation teams a practical understanding of how to adapt the system without breaking the clean core, ensuring long-term upgradeability and compliance.

1.2 Why Extensibility is Especially Important for EHS

From our project experience, EHS is one of the most extensibility-driven domains in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud because:

  • Regulations differ significantly by country (e.g. OSHA, EU directives, etc.)
  • Incident reports must reflect local legal requirements
  • Customers require tailored analytics and KPIs
  • Integration with external safety systems is common
  • Forms and regulatory outputs often need custom structures

EHS processes must adapt to organizational legal, and operational needs. Extensibility in Public Cloud ensures this adaptability without compromising SAP’s clean-core principles.

 

2. Extensibility Options in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides a comprehensive extensibility portfolio designed to support innovation without compromising the stability of the core system. These capabilities range from low-code configuration tools for business users to pro-code development environments for technical teams. Understanding these options is essential for designing scalable, future-proof EHS solutions – especially in Public Cloud environments where clean-core principles are mandatory.

Extensibility Portfolio for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Own illustration based on SAP source: https://www.sap.com/documents/2018/05/606d1ee8-037d-0010-87a3-c30de2ffd8ff.html)

2.1 Low-Code vs. Pro-Code Extensibility

The extensibility portfolio is structured along two axes:

  • Low-Code: Target at key user and functional experts who need to quickly adapt user interfaces, create fields, or adjust logic without deep technical development.
  • Pro-Code: Designed for professional developers who require advanced capabilities through the ABAP Cloud development model or SAP BTP services.

These options are distributed across two major extensibility categories: On-Stack Extensibility (In-App) & Side-by-Side Extensibility.

2.2 On-Stack Extensibility (In-App)

Executed directly inside SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, following the clean-core principles enforced by SAP.

Key User & Developer Extensibility

2.2.1 Key User Extensibility (Low-Code)

Accessible directly via the SAP Fiori Launchpad, key user extensibility enables business focused adjustments such as:

  • UI adaptation mode: Modify screen layouts, hide/show fields, rearrange sections.
  • Custom fields: Create and publish custom fields that automatically extend UI, APIs, CDS views, and reports.
  • Custom logic (using BAdIs or BDEF extensions): Implement small logic enhancements using predefined extensions points.
  • Custom business objects: Model simple new business objects without coding.
  • Custom CDS views & OData services: Build analytical and integration-ready views with drag-and-drop tooling.
  • Analytical queries and applications: Extend reporting and KPIs in SAP Fiori or SAP Analytics Cloud.

Key User Extensibility is ideal for EHS teams that need to adapt processes quickly, e.g. adding a regulatory field in Incident Management or creating country-specific reporting structures.

2.2.2 Developer Extensibility (Pro-Code)

Developer Extensibility is performed using ABAP Cloud in Eclipse via ABAP Development Tools (ADT), enabling professional developers to build upgrade-safe extensions inside the SAP S/4HANA Cloud stack.

Typical capabilities include:

  • UI adaptation projects via SAP Business Application Studio
  • Extension fields built using professional ABAP development tools
  • Custom logic (BAdIs and BDEF extensions) with advanced editor capabilities
  • RAP Business Objects (full-fledge RESTful ABAP applications)
  • CDS views and OData services with full development tooling
  • Analytical queries and custom analytical content

This level of extensibility is used when EHS implementations require more complex data models, multi-step validations, or custom processes beyond the key user scope.

2.3 Side-by-Side Extensibility

When requirements cannot be fulfilled within the S/4HANA Cloud stack, SAP BTP provides a powerful platform for building complementary applications:

  • SAP Build Apps (no-code mobile and web apps)
  • SAP Build Process Automation (workflows and automations)
  • SAP Build Work Zone (custom dashboard and portals)
  • SAP Build Code / CAP (cloud-native pro-code development, Node.js/Java)
  • ABAP Environment on BTP (Steampunk) for ABAP Cloud side-by-side extensions

Side-by-side extensibility is particularly relevant for EHS when:

  • complex mobile solutions are required (e.g. hazard observations, audits)
  • workflow automation or robotic processing is desired
  • large-scale integration scenarios (e.g., IoT sensors, safety systems) are needed
  • custom employee or contractor portals must be built

Although side-by-side extensibility plays an important role in the overall SAP extensibility strategy, we will not dive deeper into BTP-based extensions in this blog post. Our objective is to demonstrate what can be achieved directly within the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, using standard in-app extensibility options that remain fully aligned with SAP’s clean-core principles. Based on our project experience, most EHS related enhancements such as custom fields, logic, reporting extensions, and form adaptations can be delivered efficiently using Key User or Developer Extensibility (on-stack). For this reason, the upcoming chapters focus exclusively on in-app, upgrade-safe extensibility scenarios that can be implemented without additional BTP architecture.

2.4 BAdIs in the Public Cloud (Key User vs. Developer Access)

Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) are predefined extension points provided by SAP that allow injecting custom logic while staying upgrade safe. You can explore the available BAdIs for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud here: Business Add-Ins | SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

There are two categories in S/4HANA Public Cloud:

Key User BAdIs

  • Implemented through the Custom Logic SAP Fiori app
  • Available only for selected business contexts
  • Designed for simple enhancements such as: Validation rules, Derivation of field values, Basic calculations

Developer BAdIs

  • Implemented using ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in SAP BTP ABAP Environment or Embedded Steampunk
  • Allow more complex coding scenarios
  • Enable interaction with APIs, CDS views, RAP BOs and advanced data handling

In EHS specifically, SAP provides a growing set of BAdIs – particularly in Incident Management and Emissions Management – which are essential for country specific reporting, custom form generation, or regulatory compliance.

The following list provides an overview of the EHS-specific BAdIs that are currently available in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Incident Management

  • BAdI: Change of Field Values in BG (Berufsgenossenschaft) Incident Report (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Basic Information (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Custom Field Incident Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Involved Person Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Root Data (Key User)

Risk Management

  • (No BAdIs available for Risk Management in Public Cloud yet)

Emissions Management

  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Amount Root (Key User)
  • BAdI: Check Amounts State and Perform Subsequent Actions (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Generation of Export Files (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Compliance Requirement Import from XLSX (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import from XLSX BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection XLSX Parser BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Data Collection Root (Key User)

As the overview shows, the currently available BAdIs for EHS in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are primarily focused on Key User Extensibility, especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management. While Developer Extensibility via ABAP Cloud provides a more advanced pro-code extension model, the current EHS-specific enhancement points are mostly delivered as in-app, low-code BAdIs to ensure upgrade stability and full alignment with SAP’s clean core principles.

This corresponds closely with our experience from project implementations: Most EHS extension requirements can be delivered efficiently using in-app, Key User Extensibility tools such as Custom Fields, Custom Logic, UI Adaptation, and CDS View extensions without requiring developer access.

 

3. Practical Extensibility Scenarios in EHS

In chapter 2, we explored the extensibility options available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and outlined which of these options are most relevant for EHS implementations. As highlighted, the majority of extensibility points currently exposed in the EHS area (especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management) are implemented using Key User Extensibility, including custom fields, UI adaptation, form template configuration, and Custom Logic BAdIs.

Because of this, this chapter focuses exclusively on Key User Extensibility in practice, demonstrating how customers can solve real-world EHS requirements entirely within the Public Cloud without requiring developer extensibility or SAP BTP side-by-side extensions.

Drawing from our project experience, we selected two scenarios that reflect common customer requirements:

  1. Adding custom attributes to the Incident Management process
  2. Generating a country-specific incident report, using custom form templates and multiple BAdIs

Both scenarios illustrate how far customers can go using the extensibility tools embedded in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, while fully adhering to the clean-core principle.

3.1 Example 1 - Introducing a Custom Attribute for Incident Records

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Custom Fields App (SAP Fiori App)
  • UI Adaptation (SAP Fiori Settings)

3.1.1 Business Requirement

Many organizations require an additional field “Business Unit” to be captured as part of incident documentation to meet internal reporting needs, support organizational analysis, or fulfill local compliance requirements. Since this information is not available in the standard SAP EHS Public Cloud data model, customers often need to introduce it as a custom field.

Typically, the Business Unit may be required in multiple stages of the Incident Management process, such as:

  • Incident Creation
  • Incident Processing
  • Reporting and Analytics Dashboards

In our case, the Business Unit field was only added to the Incident Processing step, primarily for simplicity and to demonstrate the extensibility approach in clear and focused manner. However, this field can be added to additional UIs and process steps as needed, depending on the customer’s specific requirements, organizational structure, or compliance obligations.

3.1.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Create New Custom Field

In this step a custom field for the Incident Management will be created using the “Custom Fields” Fiori App. You can follow the steps below to create a custom field:

1. Navigate to the “Custom Fields” app from the Fiori Launchpad.

2. Click “Create”.

3. Enter the following details:

  • Business Context: Select the relevant context (e.g. EHHSS_INC_BINFA).
  • Label: Provide a meaningful name (Business Unit). Identifier & Tooltip will be filled automatically.
  • Type: Choose from options like Text, Number, Date, etc.
  • Length: Define the size of the field if applicable.

Create New Field

After the required details have been filled, select Create and Edit.

4. Enable the fields for the relevant applications.

The fields of the tabs User Interfaces, Analytics and APIs will be enabled by default. These tabs are required to support user interactions, reporting as well as integrations for the recently added custom field (Business Unit).

Field Enablement

If the new field should appear in generated documents such as PDFs or reports, you need to enable the required Form Templates. In our scenario, two Form Templates were activated as shown below.

Enabled Form Templates

Note: The YY1_WHS_FORM10 Template is a custom Form Template. The creation of this Form Template will be shown in chapter 3.2.

5. Save and publish the custom field to make it available in the system.

 

Assign custom field to Fiori app

Custom fields created by using the “Custom Fields” Fiori app can be assigned to the relevant Fiori applications based on the selected business context. Follow these steps to add the field:

1. Open the “Manage Incident” Fiori app & click on any incident.

2. Click on your profile & choose “Adapt UI”

Navigate to "Adapt UI"

 3. Once Adapt UI is activated, you can start customizing the page layout and add the recently created custom field to the relevant sections. By selecting “Customize” > “Show Customizable Areas” as shown below, you will be able to insert the new custom field “Business Unit” into the desired section of the Fiori App.

Navigate to "Show Customizable Areas"

 4. Select the Customizable Area that should be changed.

Select Customizable Area

 5. Select the element as shown below & click on “Customize UIBB”.

Select "Customize UIBB"

 6. To add the new field, select “Element” > “Add Element”.

Add Element

 7. Select the recently created field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN and select “OK”.

Select field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN

 

In the below shown illustration you can see an example, after the Business Unit was added to the UI.

Field Business Unit added to UI

 8. Save the UI adaptation for this page.  

 

3.2 Example 2 - Generating a Country-Specific Incident Report

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Adobe Lifecycle Designer (External Tool)
  • Maintain Form Template App (SAP Fiori App)
  • Custom Logic App (SAP Fiori App)
  • CBC Configuration (SAP Public Cloud) / or if no access exists Implementation Activities (SAP Fiori App)

3.2.1 Business Requirement

In many EHS implementations, customers need to generate country-specific incident reports that comply with national legal requirements. These reports often require a combination of standard fields, people related information, and custom fields that are not provided in the SAP EHS Public Cloud standard forms. For example, organizations operating in Australia may be required to submit the WHS Form 10, a mandatory workplace health and safety report documenting incidents, injuries, or hazards in accordance with the Australian Work Health and Safety (WHS) Regulations (made-up). To support this requirement, a custom Adobe form template must be created and populated with incident data, including custom fields. This requires implementing the relevant Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) to retrieve, map, and supply the correct incident information into the custom form.

The report must include:

  • Basic incident details
  • Person and involvement information
  • Custom fields required for the local legislative format

3.2.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Develop a Custom Form in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

A custom form template needs to be created to meet the specific requirements of the report. The form should include all necessary fields. To showcase this example, we created the form template YY1_WHS_FORM10 in Adobe Lifecycle Designer and saved it as an xdp file.

Form Template Creation in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

 

Upload Custom Form in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Once the custom form template is created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer, the next step is to upload it to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud by using the “Maintain Form Template” app.

1. Open the “Maintain Form Template” app in your SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

2. Navigate to the “Custom Template” tab.

3. Click “New” to create a new entry.

4. Enter a Form Template Name of your choice (for example “YY1_WHS_FORM10” including the prefix “YY1_” for custom forms).

5. Upload the form file that you created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer.

6. Select the Data Source Name as “EHSS_FDP_INCIDENT_SRV”.

The illustration below shows how the form setup was done in our scenario.

Form Setup (1)

Form Setup (2)

 

Assign Custom Fields & Custom Logic to the form

In this step we assign the created custom fields & logic to the form (shown in the previous step). This is achieved by using the “Custom Logic” app in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, where you can leverage the available Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) provided by the system. To retrieve the required information in the form, you can implement the following BAdIs:

  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PERS
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

1. Click “Create” to start a new implementation.

2. Select one of the mentioned BAdIs above and proceed to “Step 2” (if no filters are needed jump over to step 3 and enter an Implementation Description).

3. Create and publish the Implementation.

4. Navigate to the created Implementation.

Created Implementations

 5. Select “Code Editor” and write ABAP logic using released APIs and CDS views.

Open Code Editor

The below shown BAdI implementation YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO retrieves incident basic information from the CDS View I_IncidentBasicInfo and populates the INCIDENTBASICINFO structure, so that key fields such as the Creation Date Time or Business Unit (which was previously created as a custom field in chapter 3.1) are available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO

Perform the same steps for the other required BadIs.

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE retrieves involved person details, such as Person’s Full Name, from the CDS View I_IncidentInvolvedPerson which makes it available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT retrieves root-level incident data such as CreationDateTime from the CDS View I_Incident and makes these fields available for the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

Note: BAdIs are essential because they supply data for custom and standard fields in the form. Without these implementations, the fields would remain empty, as the standard logic does not retrieve the required CDS view information.

6. Click “Publish” to implement.

 

Functional Configuration (Assign Form to regulation)

Uploading the Adobe form just makes the template available in the system. To actually use it in the EHS process, you need to specify the form and assign it to the correct form group and regulation. This ensures the form is linked to the appropriate compliance context and can be selected when generating reports.

This can be achieved by performing the mentioned steps below performed in the SAP Central Business Configuration (or ”Implementation Activities” app).

1. Specify form: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Forms

Each form entry shows key technical attributes:

  • Form Name & Form Title : Represents the form to be specified (In our scenario: WHS).
  • Form Type: Indicates the technology used for the form. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, this is typically “SAP Interactive Form”, which refers to Adobe-based forms used for output and reporting.
  • Form Controller: Controls the rendering and behavior of the form in SAP (In our scenario: CL_EHFND_FW_ADS_OM_FORM_CTRL).
  • Data Provider: Supplies the data from the EHS process to the form (In our scenario: CL_EHHSS_AIF_INCIDENT_DPROV).
  • Form Object Name: Identifies the form template used for output. This should match the custom form you uploaded earlier in the “Maintain Form Template” app (In our scenario: YY1_WHS_FORM10).

Specify Form

 2. Assign Form to the Form Group: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration  > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Form Groups and Assign Forms

Assign Form to Form Group (1)

After defining the form groups, the next step is to assign the relevant specified forms to these groups. This can be performed on the second level of the selected form group and ensures that the custom or standard forms are correctly linked to the appropriate reporting or regulatory context.

Assign Form to Form Group (2)

 3. Specify Regulations & assign Regulation to Incidents: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety >  Specify Regulations.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (1)

After specifying the regulation (e.g., WHS), the next step is to assign it to the relevant incident categories. This ensures that when users select a regulation in the Incident process, the correct forms from the assigned form group become available for reporting.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (2)

 4. Assign the Forms to Regulations: Finally, link the forms to the corresponding regulation. This step ensures that when a regulation (e.g., WHS) is selected in the Incident process, the correct form becomes available for reporting.

Therefore, open the SAP Central Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Assign Forms to Regulations.

Assign Forms to Regulations

 

Generating the Report

Once the configuration is complete, you can generate the report directly from the “Manage Incident” app.

1. Open the “Manage Incident” app

2. Select any Incident which has the status  “In Process”.

3. Click on “Regulations”, choose “WHS”, then click “OK” and” Save”.

Generate Report (1)

After selecting the WHS regulation, the system makes the corresponding report option available under the “Reports” tab.

4. Navigate to the “Reports” tab.

5. Select the WHS Report from the list.

6. Click “Generate” to create the report.

Generate Report (2)

Once you click “Generate” for the selected Report Type, the WHS report is created and appears in the list as a downloadable PDF.

Generate Report (3)

The final output reflects all required incident details, including custom and standard fields, in the WHS Form 10 format.

Output

 

4. Summary & Lessons Learned

Extensibility plays a critical role in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementations for Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS). As demonstrated throughout this blog post, even highly regulated processes such as incident reporting or country-specific compliance documentation can be effectively supported using SAP’s clean-core extensibility framework.

Drawing from our project experience and the two practical use cases presented, this chapter summarizes the key takeaways and highlights the most important lessons learned when implementing extensibility in EHS Public Cloud.

4.1 Key Takeaways

Clean-Core Extensibility Is Not a Limitation – It is a Design Principle

The SAP Public Cloud model enforces strict boundaries around what can be extended. Rather than restricting customers, these boundaries ensure:

  • Long-term upgrade protection
  • Predictable lifecycle behavior
  • Lower maintenance effort
  • Full SAP supportability

All enhancements must therefore rely on SAP-released extension points.

Most EHS Requirements Can Be Solved with Key User Extensibility

A major insight from our implementations is that the majority of EHS use cases do not require developer extensibility or side-by-side applications.

Key User tools already cover:

  • Custom data fields
  • UI adaptations
  • PDF report adjustments
  • BAdI logic

Both examples in this blog were fully implemented using Key User Extensibility only.

BAdIs Are the Backbone of EHS Extensibility

SAP delivers a growing catalogue of EHS specific BAdIs in the Public Cloud, particularly for:

  • Incident Management
  • Emissions Management

Key lessons:

  • Each BAdI is designed for a very specific business context.
  • You often need to use several BAdIs together to populate a report for a form.
  • They enable retrieving structured data via released CDS Views and APIs.
  • Clean and modular implementations significantly improve maintainability.

Custom Forms Require a Structured Approach

Regulatory reports require a combination of:

  • A form template (Adobe)
  • Custom fields
  • BAdI logic
  • CBC configuration

The lesson: Form extensibility is not only a technical activity – it is a cross-functional exercise involving business, logic, and configuration layers.

Configuration in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC) / Implementation Activities is Essential

EHS reporting relies heavily on CBC / Implementation Activities, especially when assigning:

  • Forms > form groups
  • Form groups > regulations
  • Regulations > incident categories

A common project challenge: Without correct CBC (or Implementation Activities) configuration, even perfectly implemented forms and BAdIs will not appear in the UI.

End-to-End Testing Is Crucial

Because EHS extensions span UI, logic, reporting and configuration layers, testing must always validate the entire lifecycle:

  • Incident creation > processing > regulation selection > report generation

This avoids fragmented testing and ensures that all extension layers work together seamlessly.

4.2 Lessons Learned

Start With the Simplest Possible Extension Option

Always begin with Key User tools before considering Developer Extensibility or SAP BTP. Public Cloud projects succeed when complexity is added only where absolutely necessary.

Choose BAdIs Wisely – Don’t Over-Engineer

Each BAdI serves a narrow purpose. Trying to force a single BAdI to solve multiple needs often causes issues later. Modular, purpose-aligned implementations are easier to maintain and debug.

Document Custom Logic and Configuration Thoroughly

Because Public Cloud enforces strict structure, even small enhancements should be:

  • Named consistently (YY1_*)
  • Documented cleanly (purpose, input, output)
  • Readable for team members who join the project later.

Well-documented extensions also reduce future rework during audits or regulatory updates.

Maintain a Strong Governance Around Extensibility

Typical governance measures include:

  • Reviewing whether a need truly requires an extension
  • Maintaining a central register of custom fields and BAdIs
  • Ensuring no duplicate fields are created
  • Enforcing naming conventions

This prevents uncontrolled growth of extensions over time.

Engage Business Users Early in the Design Process

EHS professionals often know exactly how regulations should be represented. Early involvement helps:

  • Avoid unnecessary extensions
  • Validate report layouts
  • Confirm the accuracy of populated data
  • Ensure usability in real operational scenarios

Plan for Future Regulatory Requirements

EHS compliance evolves frequently. When building extensions, always think ahead:

  • Could this field or form be reused for another regulation?
  • Can we structure the logic to accommodate more categories in the future?
  • Are we using modular BAdI implementations that can scale?

This significantly reduces technical dept.

4.3 Best Practices

To close this chapter, here is a consolidated best-practice checklist:

  • Use SAP-released extension points only (clean core).
  • Prefer Key User Extensibility for EHS whenever possible.
  • Keep BAdI implementations modular and business-context specific.
  • Use functional naming conventions for fields, forms, and BAdIs.
  • Perform end-to-end lifecycle testing (UI > logic > form > CBC).
  • Document every extension early, including purpose and data sources.
  • Reuse released CDS Views and APIs – never rely on unreleased objects.
  • Involve business users early to ensure regulatory accuracy.
  • Build form templates in a future-proof, scalable structure.
  • Maintain strong governance to avoid unnecessary or duplicate extensions.

4.4 Final Remark

Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is not about pushing technical boundaries. It is about using the right tools to deliver business value while protecting system integrity. With a structured approach, as illustrated in both examples, customers can achieve regulatory compliance, process optimization, and system flexibility without compromising the clean-core principles that define the Public Cloud.
